note.p: "The epistle dedicatorie" signed: Fra. Kirkman, Jun.
Unjustifiably ascribed to Marlowe. Possibly identical with "The Spanish Moor's tragedy," by Dekker, Haughton and Day. Cf. Cambridge hist. of Eng. lit. ; DNB.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

div.p: Lusts Dominion; OR, THE Lascivious Queen. A TRAGEDIE.
LONDON, Printed for F. K. and are to be sold by Robert Pollard, at the sign of Ben. Johnsons head, on the back-side of the Old-Exchange. 1657.

list.item: Eleazar the Moor, Prince of Fesse and Barbary.
Philip King of Spain, Father to Fernando, Philip, and Isabella.
Fernando King of Spain Philip Prince of Spain Sons to Philip.
Alvero a Nobleman, and Father in Law to Eleazar, and Father to Hortenzo and Maria.
Christofero Roderigo two Noblemen of Spain.
Hortenzo Lover to Isabella, and son to Alvero.
Zarack, Baltazar two Moors, attending Eleazar.
The Queen Mother of Spain, and wife K. Philip.
Maria wife to Eleazar, and daughter Alvero.

div.p: Lusts Dominion. OR, The Lascivious Queen. A TRAGEDY.
LONDON: Printed for Fr. Kirkman at the John Fletchers Head over against the Angel-Inn on the backside of St. Clements without Temple-Barre, 1661.

div.head: To my worthily honored Friend William Carpenter, Esquire.
div.p:
MY Ambition hath long soared so high, as to prompt me to somewhat whereby I might in part render to you my gratitude: and not yet finding any service I can act for you, a sufficient or competent return of any part of those many favours you have still honored me withall; I took on me the resolution
(rather then to be thought wholly negligent of you) to lay hold on this means of rendring you my service. SIR! This Piece, which without your favour and command had never past the Presse, I here present to you with this confidence, that as you were instrumental in its production to the world, so your name and favour will be sufficient to protect it from the calumny of this censorious age In doing of which you will multiply those obligations you have conferred upon

closer.signed: Your devoted servant FRA. KIRKMAN. June

div.head: Lusts Dominion; OR, THE Lascivious Queen.
A TRAGEDIE.
Scena Ima.
div.stage: Enter Zaracke, Baltazar, two Moors taking tobacco musick sounding within: enter Queen Mother of Spain with two Pages, Eleazar sitting on a chair suddenly draws the curtain.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: ON me, do's musick spend this sound on me
That hate all unity: hah: Zarack Baltazar?

sp.speaker: Que. Mo.
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Are you there with your Beagles? hark you slaves,
Did not I bind you on your lives, to watch that none disturb'd us.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Gentle Eleazar.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: There, off: Is't you that deafs me with this noise?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why is my loves asspect so grim and horrid?
Look smoothly on me:
Chyme out your softest strains of harmony,
And on delicious Musicks silken wings
Send ravishing delight to my loves ears,
That he may be enamored of your tunes.
Come let's kisse.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, no, saies I; and twice away saies stay:
Come, come, I'le have a kiss, but if you strive
For one denial you shall forfeit five.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nay prithee good Queen leave me,
I am now sick, heavie, and dull as lead.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I'le make thee lighter by taking something from thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Do: take from mee this Ague and these fits that hanging on me
Shake me in pieces, and set all my blood
A boiling with the fire of rage: away, away
Thou believ'st I jeast: and laugh'st, to see my wrath wear antick shapes:
Be gone, be gone.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What means my love, burst all those wyres? burn all those Instruments?
For they displease my Moor. Art thou now pleas'd,
Or wert thou now disturb'd? I'le wage all Spain
To one sweet kisse, this is some new device
To make me fond and long. Oh! you men
Have tricks to make poor women die for you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What die for me; away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Away, what way? I prithee speak more kindly;
Why do'st thou frown? at whom?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: At thee.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: At me? Oh why at me? for each contracted frown
A crooked wrinkle interlines my brow:
Spend but one hour in frowns, & I shal look
Like to a Beldam of one hundred years:
I prithee speak to me and chide me not,
I prithee chide if I have done amisse,
But let my punishment be this, and this.
I prithee smile on me, if but a while,
Then frown on me, I'le die: I prithee smile:
Smile on me, and these two wanton boies,
these pretty lads that do attend on me,
Shall call thee Jove, shall wait upon thy cup
And fill thee Nectar: their enticing eies
Shal serve as chrystal, wherein thou maist see
To dresse thy self, if thou wilt smile on me.
Smile on me, and with coroners of pearle,
And bells of gold, circling their pretty arms
In a round Ivorie fount these two shal swim,
And dive to make thee sport:
Bestow one smile, one little little smile,
And in a net of twisted silk and gold
In my all-naked arms, thy self shalt lie.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why, what to do? Lusts arms do stretch so wide.
That none can fill them? I'le lay there away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Where hast thou learn'd this language? that can say
No more but two rude words; away, away:
Am I grown ugly now?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ugly as hell.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou lovd'st me once.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: That can thy bastards tell.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What is my sin? I will amend the same.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hence strumpet, use of sin makes thee past shame.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: I Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Too true 'tis, woe is me;
I am a Strumpet, but made so by thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By me; no, no; by these young bauds; fetch thee a glasse
And thou shalt see the bals of both thine eies
Burning in fire of lust; by me? there's here
Within this hollow cistern of thy breast
A spring of hot blood: have not I to cool it
Made an extraction to the quintessence
Even of my soul: melted all my spirits,
Ravish'd my youth, deflour'd my lovely cheeks.
And dried this, this to anatomy
Only to feed your lust, (these boies have ears):
Yet wouldst thou murther me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I murder thee?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I cannot ride through the Castilian streets
But thousand eies through windows, and through doors
Throw killing looks at me, and every slave
At Eleazar darts a finger out,
And every hissing tongue cries, There's the Moor,
That's he that makes a Cuckold of our King,
there go's the Minion of the Spanish Queen;
That's the black Prince of Divels, there go's hee
That on smooth boies, on Masks and Revellings
Spends the Revenues of the King of Spain.
Who arms this many headed beast but you,
Murder & Lust are twins, and both are thine;
Being weary of me thou wouldst worry me,
Because some new love makes thee loath thine old.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Eleazar!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Harlot! I'le not hear thee speak.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I'le kill my self unless thou hear'st me speak.
My husband King upon his death-bed lies,
Yet have I stolne from him to look on thee;
A Queen hath made her self thy Concubine:
Yet do'st thou now abhor me, hear me speak!
Else shall my sons plague thy adult'rous wrongs,
And tread upon thy heart for murd'ring me,
Thy tongue hath murd'red me (Cry murder boyes)

sp.speaker: 2 Boies
sp.l: Murder! the Queen's murd'red!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Love? slaves peace?

sp.speaker: 2 Boies
sp.l: Murder! the Queen's murd'red!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stop your throats?
Hark Hush you Squales; Dear love look up:
Our Chamber window stares into the Court,
And every wide mouth'd ear, hearing this news
Will give Alarum to the cuckold King.
I did dissemble when I chid my love,
And that dissembling was to try my love

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou call'dst me strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le tear out my tongue

From this black temple for blaspheming
thee.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And when I woo'd thee but to smile on me,
Thou cri'dst, away, away, and frown'dst upon mee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come now I'le kiss thee, now I'le smile upon thee;
Call to thy ashy cheeks their wonted red:
Come frown not, pout not, smile, smile, but upon me
And with my poniard will I stab my flesh,
And quaffe carrowses to thee of my blood,
Whil'st in moist Nectar kisses thou do'st pledge me.
How now, why star'st thou thus?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: The King is dead.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! dead! you hear this, is't true, is't true, the King dead!
Who dare knock thus?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: It is the Cardinall, making inquiry if the Queen were here.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: See? shee's here, tell him? and yet Zarack stay.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Don Roderigo's come to seek the Queen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why should Roderigo seek her here?

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: The King hath swounded thrice, and being recovered,
Sends up and down the Court, to seek her grace.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The King was dead with you; Run? and with a voice.
Erected high as mine, say thus, thus threaten
To Roderigo and the Cardinall.
Seek no Queens here, I'le broach them if they do,
Upon my falchions point. Again more knocking!

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Your father is at hand, my Gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Lock all the chambers, bar him out you apes.
Hither, a vengeance; stir Eugenia,
You know your old walk under ground, away.
So down hye to the King, quick, quick, you Squalls
Crawle with your Dam, i'ch dark, dear love farewell,
One day I hope to shutt you up in hell.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: SOn Eleazar, saw you not the Queen?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Was not the Queen here with you?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Queen with mee; because my Lord I'me married to your daughter:
You (like your daughter) will grow Jealous,
The Queen with me, with me, a Moore, a Devill,
A slave of Barbary, a dog; for so
Your silken Courtiers christen me, but father
Although my flesh be tawny, in my veines,
Runs blood as red, and royal as the best
And proud'st in Spain, there do'es old man: my father,
Who with his Empire, lost his life,
And left me Captive to a Spanish Tyrant, Oh!
Go tell him! Spanish Tyrant? tell him, do?
He that can loose a kingdom and not rave,
He's a tame jade, I am not, tell old Philip
I call him Tyrant here's a sword & arms,
A heart, a head, and so pish, 'tis but death:
Old fellow shee's not here. But ere I dye,
Sword I'le bequeath thee a rich legacy.

sp.speaker: Alvero
sp.l: Watch fitter hours to think on wrongs then now,
Deaths frozen hand hold's Royal Philip's heart,
Halfe of his body lies within a grave;
Then do not now by quarrells shake that state,
Which is already too much ruinate.
Come and take leave of him before he dye.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le follow you, now purple villany;
Sit like a Roab imperiall on my back,
That under thee I closelyer may contrive
My vengeance; foul deeds hid do sweetly thrive:
Mischief erect thy throne and sit in state
Here, here upon this head; let fools fear fate.
Thus I defie my starrs, I care not I
How low I tumble down, so I mount high.
Old time I'le wait bare-headed at thy heels,
and be a foot-boy to thy winged hours;
They shall not tell one Minute out in sands,
But I'le set down the number, I'le stil wake,
And wast these bals of sight by tossing them;
In bu●e observations upon thee.
Sweet opportunity I'le bind my self
to thee in base apprentice-hood so long,
Till on thy naked scalp grow hair as thick
As mine: & all hands shal lay hold on thee,
If thou wilt lend me but thy rusty sithe,
To cut down all that stand within my wrongs,
And my revenge. Love dance in twenty formes
Upon my beauty, that this Spanish dame
May be bewitch'd, and doat, her amorous flames
Shall blow up the old King. Consume his Sons,
And make all Spain a bonefire.
This Tragedie beeing acted hers does begin,
To shed a harlots blood can be no sin.

div.head: Scena 3tia.
div.stage: The Courtains being drawn there appears in his bed King Phillip, with his Lords, the Princesse Isabella, at the feet Mendoza, Alvero, Hortensio, Fernando, Roderigo, and to them Enter Queen in hast.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: WHose was that Screech-Owls voice, that like the sound
Of a hell tortur'd soul rung through mine ears
Nothing but horrid shreiks, nothing but death?
Whil'st I, vailing my knees to the cold earth,
Drowning my withered cheeks in my warm tears,
And stretching out my arms to pull from heaven
Health for the Royal Majestie of Spain,
All cry'd, The Majestie of Spain is dead:
That last word [dead] struck through the ecchoing air,
Rebounded on my heart, and smote me down
breathelesse to the cold earth, and made me leave
My praiers for Philips life, but thanks to heaven
I see him live, and lives I hope to see
Unnumbred years to guide this Empery.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: The number of my years ends in one day,
E're this Sun's down all a King's glory sets,
For all our lives are but deaths counterfeits.
Father Mendoza and you Peers of Spain,
Dry your wet eies, for sorrow wanteth force
T'inspire a breathing soul in a dead coarse;
Such is your King: Where's Isabel our Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: At your beds-feet confounded in her tears.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: She of your grief the heaviest burthen bears;
You can but lose a King, but she a Father.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: She bear the heaviest burthen; Oh say rather
I bear, and am born down, my sorrowing
Is for a husbands losse, losse of a King.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: No more, Alvero call the Princess hither.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Madam, his Majestie doth call for you.

sp.speaker: K. Ph.
sp.l: Come hither Isabella, reach a hand;
Yet now it shall not need, in stead of thine
Death shoving thee back claspe his hands in mine,
And bids me come away, I must, I must;
Though Kings be gods on earth, they turn to dust.
Is not Prince Philip come from Portugal?

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: The Prince as yet is not return'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: K. Ph.
sp.l: Commend me to him, if I ne're behold him:
This tells the order of my funeral,
Do it as 'tis set down? Embalm my body;
Though worms do make no difference of flesh;
Yet Kings are curious here to dig their graves,
Such is man's frailty; when I am embalm'd,
Apparel me in a rich Roial Robe,
According to the custome of the Land;
Then place my bones within that brazen shrine
Which death hath builded for my ancestors:
I cannot name death, but he strait steps in,
And pulls me by the arm.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: His Grace doth faint: help me my Lords softly to raise him up.

div.stage: Enter Eleazar, and stands sadly by.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Lift me not up, I shortly must go down,
When a few dribling minutes have run out;
Mine hour is ended: King of Spain farewell:
You all acknowledg him your Soveraign.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: When you are dead we will acknowledg him.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Govern this kingdom well: to be a King
Is given to many: but to govern well
Granted to few: have care to Isabel,
Her virtue was King Philips looking-glasse.
Reverence the Queen your mother. Love your sister,
And the young Prince your brother; even that day
When Spain shall solemnize my Obsequies,
And lay me up in earth; let them crown you.
Where's Eleazar, Don Alvero's son?

sp.speaker: Fernand.
sp.l: Yonder with crost arms stands he malecontent.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: I do commend him to thee for a man
Both wise and warlike, yet beware of him,
Ambition wings his spirit, keep him down;
What wil not men attempt to win a crown.
Mendoza is Protector of thy Realm,
I did elect him for his gravity,
I trust hee'l be a father to thy youth:
Call help Fernando, now I saint indeed.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: My Lords.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Let none with a distracted voice
Shreik out, and trouble me in my departure:
Heavens hands I see are beckning for my soul;
I come, I come; thus do the proudest die,
Death hath no mercy, life no certainty.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: As yet his soul's not from her temple gone.
Therefore forbear loud lamentation.

sp.speaker: Queen. Mo
sp.l: Oh he is dead, hee's dead! lament and die,
In her King's end begins Spains misery

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.l: He shall not end so soon; Father, dear Father!

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Forbear sweet Isabella, shreiks are vain.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You crie forbear, you by his losse of breath
Have won a kingdom, you may cry forbear:
But I have lost a Father, and a King;
And no tongue shal controul my sorrowing.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Whither, good Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I will go,
Where I will languish in eternal wo.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Love.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Talk not of love to me.
The world and the Worlds pride henceforth I'le scorn.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: My love shall follow thee, if thou deny'st
To live with poor Hortenzo as his wife;
I'le never change my love, but change my life.

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.l: I know he is not dead, I know proud Death
Durst not behold such sacred majesty.
Why stand you thus distracted? Mother, Brother,
My Lord Mendoza, where's my Royal father?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Here lyes the temple of his Royall soul.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Here's all that's left of Philips Majesty.
Wash you his tombe with tears; Fernandoes mone,
Hating a Partner, shall be spent alone.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh happy father, miserable Sonne!
Philip is gone to Joy Philip's forlorn:
He dies to live; my life with woe is torn.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweet sonne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet mother: oh! how I now do shame
To lay on one so foul so fair a name:
Had you been a true mother, a true wife,
This King had not so soon been robb'd of life.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What means this rage, my sonne?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Call not me your sonne:
My father whilst he liv'd tyr'd his strong armes
In bearing christian armour, gainst the Turk's
And spent his brains in warlike stratagems
To bring Confusion on damn'd Infidels;
Whil'st you that snorted here at home betraid
His name to everlasting Infamy;
Whilst you at home suffered his bed-chamber
To be a Brothelry, whilst you at home
Suffered his Queen to be a Concubine;
And wanton red cheekt boy's to be her bawds
Whilst shee reeking in that leachers armes.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Me!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Villaine 'tis thee, thou hel-begotten fiend at thee I stare.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Philip thou art a villain to dishonour me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother I am no villain; 'tis this villain
Dishonours you and me, dishonours Spain,
Dishonours all these Lords, this Divell is he, that—

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What! Oh pardon me I must throw off
All chains of duty: wert thou ten Kings sons,
Had I as many soules as I have sins:
As this from hence, so they from this should fly;
In just revenge of this Indignity.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give way, or I'le make way upon your bosoms.

sp.speaker: Eleazer.
sp.l: Did my dear Soveraigne live, sirrha that tongue.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Did but King Philip live, traytor I'de tell,—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A tale, that should rid both your soules to hell.
Tell Philip's ghost, that Philip tells his Queen,
That Philip's Queen is a Moor's Concubine:
Did the King live I'de tell him how you two,
Rip't up the entrails of his treasury:
With Masques and antick Revellings.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Words insupportable; do'st hear me boy?

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Stand you all still, and see me thus trod down.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stand you all still, yet let this divell stand here.

sp.speaker: Mendo
sp.l: Forbear sweet Prince; Eleazar, I am now
Protector to Fernando King of Spain:
By that authority and by consent
Of all these peers, I uterly deprive thee
Of all those Royalties thou hold'st in Spain,

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: Cardinall, who lends thee this Commission?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Cardinall, i'le shorten thee by the head for this.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Forward my Lord Mendoza, damne the feind:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain, consent you to this pride?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: wee doe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: For what cause? let his faith be try'd

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: His treasons needs no tryal, they're too plain;
Come not within the Court, for if you do,
To beg with Indian slaves I'le banish you.

div.stage: Exeunt all, but Alvero, Queen, and Eleazar

div.head: Act. I.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: WHy should my sonne be banished?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Of that dispute not now Alvero,
I'le to the King my sonne, it shall be try'de
If Castiles King can cool a Cardinall's pride.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: If I disgest this Gall; Oh! my Maria:
I am whipt, and rackt, and torn upon the wheel
Of giddy fortune: She and her Minions
Have got me down; and treading on my bosome.
They cry, lye still: the Cardinal
(Oh! rare) would bandy me away from Spain,
And banish me to beg; I, beg with slaves.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Conquer with patience these indignityes.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Patience; ha, ha: yes, yes: an honest Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yet smother the grief & seek revenge.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hah! banish me, s'foot, why say hey do;
Ther's Portugal a good air, & France a fine Country;
Or Barbary rich, and has Moors; the Turke
Pure Divell, and allowes enough to fat
The sides of villany; good living there:
I can live there, and there, and there,
Troth 'tis, a villain can live any where:
But say I goe from hence, I leave behind me
A Cardinall, that will laugh, I leave behind me
A Philip, that will clap his hands for joy;
And dance levaltoes through the Castile Court.
But the deep'st wound of all is this, I leave
My wrongs, dishonours, and my discontents,
Oh! unrevenged; my bed-rid enemies
Shal never be rais'd up by the strong Physical,
Curing of my sword, therefore stay still;
Many have hearts to strike, that dare not kill:
Leave me Maria: Cardinall, this disgrace,
Shall dye thy soule, as Inky as my face:
Pish, hence Maria.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To the King I'le fly.
He shall reveng my Lord's indignity.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Mendoza woo's the King to banish thee;
Startle thy wonted spirits, awake thy soul
And on thy resolution fasten wings,
Whose golden feathers may out-strip their hate,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le tye no golden fethers to my wings.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Shall they thus tread thee down which once were glad,
To Lacquey by thy conquering Chariot wheeles.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I care not, I can swallow more sower wrongs:

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: If they triumph o're thee; they spurn me down.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Look, spurn again.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: what Ice hath coold that fire,
Which sometimes made thy thoughts heaven aspire;
This patience had not wont to dwell with thee:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: 'Tis right, but now the World's chang'd you see;
Though I seem dead to you, here lives a fire,
No more, here comes the King, & my Maria;
The Spaniard loves my wife, she swears to me,
Shee's chast as the white Moon, well if she be.
Well too if shee be not, I care not, I,
I'le climb up by that love to dignitye.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Thou woo'st me to revenge thy husbands wrong,
I woo thy fair self not to wrong thy self;
Swear but to love me, and to thee I'le swear
To crown thy husband with a diadem.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Such love as I dare yeeld, I'le not deny.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: When in the golden armes of Majesty.
I am broke off; yonder thy husband stands,
I'le set him free, if thou unite my bands,
Soe much for that. Durst then the Card'nall,
Put on such insolence; tell me fair Madam,
Wher'e's your most Valiant Husband?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He see's me, and yet inquires for me.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Yonder's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Eleazar I have in my brest writ down
From her Report your late receiv'd disgrace:
My father lov'd you dearly, so will I.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: True, for my wife's sake.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: This Indignitye will I have Interest in for being your King,
You shall perceive I'le curbe my underling:
This morning is our Coronation
And father's funerall solemnized,
Be present, step into your wonted place;
wee'l guild your dim disgraces with our grace.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I thank my Soveraign that you love my wife;
I thank thee wife that thou wilt lock my head
In such strong armour, to bear off all blows;
Who dare say such wives are their husband foes:
Let's see now, by her falling I must rise.
Cardinal you die, if the King bid me live;
Philip you die for railing at me: proud Lorde you die,
That with Mendoza cry'd, Banish the Moors
And you my loving Liege, you're best fit fast
If all these live not, you must die at last.

div.trailer: The end of the first Act.

div.head: Scena. I.
div.stage: Enter two Lords, Philip his brother, Mendoza, Eleazar with him, the King Crown'd, Queen mother, Alvero, Zarack, Baltazar, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: WHy stares this Divell thus, as if pale death
Had made his eyes the dreadfull messengers
To carry black destruction to the world.
Was hee not banisht Spain?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your sacred mouth, pronounc'd the sentence of his banishment:
Then spurn the villain forth.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Who spurns the Moor, were better set his foot upon the Devill,
Do; spurn me? and this confounding arm of wrath
Shal like a thunderbolt breaking the clouds
Divide his body from his soul. Stand back.
Spurn Eleazar?

sp.speaker: Rode.
sp.l: Shall wee bear his pride.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Why not, he under went much Injurie,

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: What injury have we perform'd proud Lord?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Proud Cardinall; my unjust banishment.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: 'Twas wee that did it; and our words are laws.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Twas wee repeal'd him, and our words are laws.

sp.speaker: Zara. Baltaz.
sp.l: If not these are.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How! threatned and out-dar'd?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shal we give arm to hostile violence?
Sheath your swords, sheath them, it's wee command.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Grant Eleaz. justice my dread Leige

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: Eleazar hath had justice from our hands,
And he stands banish'd from the Court of Spain,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Have you done justice? why Lord Cardinall,
From whom do you derive authority,
To banish him the Court without our leave

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: From this, the Staffe of our Protectorship;
From this, which the last will of your dear Father
Committed to our trust: from this high place
Which lifts Mendoza's spirits beyond the pitch
Of ordinary honour, and from this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which too much over-weening Insolence Hath quite ta'ne from you, Eleazar up,
sp.stage: takes the staff from Mendoza and gives it to Eleaz.
sp.l: And from us sway this Staffe of Regency.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dare sons presume to break their fathers will?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dare Subjects counter-check their Soveraigns will?
'Tis done, and who gainsaies it is a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do Fernando, yet I am no Traitor.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: Fernando I am wrong'd by Peters Chair,
Mendoza vows revenge. I'le lay aside
My Cardinals hat, and in a wall of steel
The glorious livery of a souldier; fight for my late lost honour

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: King, thou shalt be no King for wronging me.
The Pope shall send his bulls through all thy Realm,
And pul obedience from thy Subjects hearts,
To put on armour of the Mother Church,
Curses shal fal like lightnings on your heads:
Bell, book and candle, holy water, praiers,
Shal all chim vengeance to the of Court Spain
Till they have power to conjure down that feind;
That damned Moor, that Devil, that Lucifer,
That dares aspire the staffe, the Card'nall swaid.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, I laugh yet, that the Cardinall's vext.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Laughts thou base slave, the wrinckles of that scorn
Thine own heart blood shall fill; Brother farewell,
Since you disprove the will our father left,
For base lust of a loathed Concubine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha, Concubine; who does Prince Philip mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy wife, thy daughter, base aspiring Lords,
Who to buy honour, are content to sell,
Your names to infamy, your souls to hell:
And stamp you now? do, do, for you shal see,
I go for vengeance, and she'l com with me.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: Stay, for she's here already, see proud boy.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Hold, stay this fury, if you long for blood,
Murder me first. Dear son you are a King:
Then stay the violent tempest of their wrath.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shall Kings be overswaid in their desires?

sp.speaker: Roderi.
sp.l: Shall Subjects be opress'd by tyranny?

sp.speaker: Q. Mother.
sp.l: No State shall suffer wrong, then hear mee speak,
Mendo, you have sworn you love the Queen,
Then by that love I charge you leave these arms:
Eliaz. for those favours I have given you,
Embrace the Cardinall, and be friends with him.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: And have my wife call'd strumpet to my face.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: 'Twas rage made his tongue erre, do you not know
The violent love Mendoza bears the Queen:
Then speak him fair, for in that honied breath
I'le lay a bait shall train him to his death.
Come, come, I see your looks give way to peace;
Lord Cardinall begin, and for reward,
Ere this fair setting Sun behold his bride;
Be bold to challenge love, yet be deni'd

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.l: That promise makes me yeild; my gracious Lord:
Although my disgrace hath graven its memory
On every Spaniards eye, yet shall the duty
I owe your sacred Highness; and the love
My Country challengeth, make me lay by
Hostile intendments, and return again
To the fair circle of obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Both pardon and our favour bids you welcome,
And for some satisfaction for your wrongs,
We here create you Salamanka's Duke,
But first as a true signe all grudges dye;
Shake hands with Eleazar and be friends;
This union pleaseth us, now brother Philip,
You are included in this league of love,
So is Roderigo to forget all wrongs:
Your Castle for a while shall bid us welcom,
Eleazar shall it not? It is enough,
Lords lead the way, that whil'st you feast your selves,
Fernando may find time all means to prove,
To compasse fair Maria for our love.

div.head: Scena II.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: MAdam a word now, have you wit or spirit?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: Both.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Set them both to a most gainfull task,
Our enemies are in my Castle-work.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: I; but the King's there too, it's dangerous pride,
To strike at those; that couch by a Lyons side.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Remove them:

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How? a thousand ways;
By poison, or by this, but every groom
Has skill in such base traffick; no our pollicies
Must look more strange, must flie with loftier wings:
Venge ance the higher it falls, more horror brings:
But you are cold, you dare not do.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: You have a womans heart, look you this hand,
Oh! 'tis too little to strike home.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: At whom?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Your son.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: Which son, the King?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Angels of heaven, stand like his guard about him, how? the King
Not for so many worlds as here be stars,
Sticking upon th'imbroidred firmament.
The King? he loves my wife and should he die;
I know none els would love her, let him live.
(in heaven) good Lord Philip.

sp.speaker: Queen Mother
sp.l: He shall die.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How? good good.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: By this hand.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: When, good good; when?

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: This night if Eleazer give consent;

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Why then this night Philip shal not live,
To see you kill him. Is he not your son?
A mother be the murd'rer of a brat,
That liv'd within her; hah!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother
sp.l: 'Tis for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Puh! What excuses cannot dam'd sin make
To save it self, I know you love him wel,
But that he has an eye, an eye, an eye,
To others our two hearts seem to be lock'd
Up in a case of steel, upon our love others
Dare not look, or if they dare, they cast
Squint purblind glances; who care though all see all,
So long as none dare speak, but, Philip
Knows that the Iron ribs of our villains
Are thin: Hee laughs to see them like this hand,
With chinks, and crevises, how a villanous eye,
A stabbing desperate tongue, the boy dare speak,
A mouth, a villanous mouth, lets muzzle him.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Thus.
Go you, and with a face well set do
In good sad colours; such as paint out
The cheek of that fool penitence, and with a tongue
Made clean and glib, Cull from their lazy swarm;
Some honest Friers, whom that damnation gold,
Can tempt to lay their souls to'th stake;
Seek such, they are rank and thick.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What then, I know such, what's the use?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: This is excellent.
Hire these to write books, preach and proclaim abroad,
That your son Philip is a bastard.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A bastard; do you; know a bastard? doo't;
Say conscience spake with you, and cry'd out, doo't
By this means shall you thrust him from all hopes
Of wearing Castiles diadem, and that spur
Galling his sides, he will flye out, and fling,
And grind the Cardinals heart to a new edg
Of discontent, from discontent grows treason,
And on the stalk of treason death: he's dead
By this blow, and by you; yet no blood shed.
Doo't then; by this trick, he gon!
We stand more sure in climbing high;
Care not who fall 'tis reall policie:
Are you arm'd to do this? hah!

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Sweet Moor it's done.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away then, work with boldness, and with speed;
On greatest actions greatest dangers feed.
Ha, ha, I thank thee provident creation,
That seeing in moulding me thou did'st intend,
I should prove villain, thanks to thee and nature
That skilful workman; thanks for my face,
Thanks that I have not wit to blush.
What Zarack? ho Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nearer, so silence;
Hang both your greedy ears upon my lips,
Let them devour my speech, suck in my breath;
And in who lets it break prison, here's his death,
This night the Card'nall shall be murd'red.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: And to fill up a grave Philip dies:

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: By thee; and slave by thee:
Have you hearts and hands to execute?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Here's both.

sp.speaker: 1 Moor.
sp.l: He dies were he my father.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Ho away?
Stay, go, go, stay, see me no more till night;
Your cheeks are black, let not your souls look white:

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Till night.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Till night, a word, the Mo Qu.
Is trying if she can with fire of gold,
Warpe the green consciences of two covetous Friers,
To preach abroad Philip's bastardy.

sp.speaker: 1 Moor.
sp.l: His bastardy, who was his father?

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Who?
Search for these friers, hire them to work with you;
Their holy callings will approve the fact.
Most good and meritorious; sin shines clear,
When her black face Religions masque doth wear.

div.stage: Aside. Here comes the Queen, good; and the Friers.

div.head: Scena. III.
div.stage: Enter two Friers, Crab and Cole; and Queen Mother.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: YOur son a bastard; say we do,
But how then shall we deal with you?
I tell you as I said before;
His being a bastard, you are so poor
In honour and in name, that time
Can never take away the crime.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I grant that Frier, yet rather I'le endure
The wound of infamy, to kill my name,
Then to see Spain bleeding, with civil swords
The boy is proud, ambitious, he woo's greatnesse,
He takes up Spanish hearts on trust, to pay them
When he shall finger Castiles Crown: Oh then
Were it not better my disgrace were known,
Then such a base aspirer fill the Throne.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Ha brother Crab, what think you?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: As you dear brother Cole:

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Then wee agree,
Coles Judgment is as Crabs you see.
Lady we swear to speak and write,
What you please so all go right.

sp.speaker: Queen. Mo.
sp.l: Then as wee gave directions, spread abroad,
In Cales, Madrid, Granado, and Medyna;
And all the Royall Cities of the Realm:
Th' ambitious hopes of that proud bastard Philip,
And somtimes as you see occasion,
Tickle the ears of the Rude multitude,
With Eleazars praises; guild his virtues,
Naples recovery and his victories
Atchieved against the Turkish Ottoman:
Will you do this for us?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Say will you?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why start you back and stare? ha? are you afraid.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: Oh? no Sir, no, but truth to tell;
Seeing your face, we thought of hell.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hell is a dream.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: But none do dream in hell.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Friers stand to her; and me; and by your sin,
I'le shoulder out Mendoza from his seat;
And of two Friers create you Cardinalls,
Oh! how would Cardinalls hats on these heads sit.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: This face would look most goodly under it:
Frier, Crab and Cole do swear,
In those circles still to appear:
In which she, or you, do charge us rise;
For you, our lives wee'l sacrifice.
Valete, Gaudete;
Sipereamus flete;
Orate pro nobis,
Oramus pro vobis.
Cole will be burnt, and Crab be prest;
Ere they prove knaves, thus are you crost and blest.

sp.speaker: Eleaz,
sp.l: Away; you know now Madam none shall throw
Their leaden envie in an opposite scale,
To weigh down our true golden happiness.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Yes, there is one.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: One, who? give mee his name and I will
Turn it to a magick spell,
To bind him here, here, who?

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Your wife Maria.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hah! my Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: She's th' Hellespont divides my love and me,
Shee being cut off.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay, stay, cut off; let's think upon't, my wife?
Humh! Kill her too!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Do's her love make thee cold?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Had I a thousand wives, down go they all:
She dies, I'le cut her off: now Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Madam, the King intreats your company.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: His pleasure be obey'd, dear love farewell;
Remember your Maria.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here a dieu;
With this I'le guard her, whil'st it stabs at you.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: My Lord! the Friers are won to joine with us.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: Be prosperous about it Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: The watch word.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Oh! the word let it be treason;
When we cry treason, break ope chamber doors:
Kill Phillip and the Cardinall; Hence

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: I fly.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Murder, now ride in triumph, darknesse, horror;
Thus I invoke your aid, your Act begin;
Night is a glorious Roab, for th'ugliest fin.

div.head: Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Cole and Crab in Trouses, the Cardinall in one of their weeds, and Philip putting on the other.

sp.speaker: Both Friers.
sp.l: PUt on my Lord, and flye or else you die.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will not, I will die first; Cardinall,
Prithe good Cardinal pluck off, Friers, slave,
Murder us two, he shall not by this sword.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord, you will endanger both our lives.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I care not; I'le kill some before I die:
Away, s'heart take your raggs; Moor, Devill, come.

sp.speaker: 2. Friers.
sp.l: My Lord put on, or else.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Gods foot come help:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Ambitious villain. Philip, let us fly
Into the chamber of the Mother Queen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thunder, beat down the lodgings.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Else let's break into the chamber of the King:

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.l: Agreed,
A pox upon those Iowzy gaberdines,
Agreed, I am for you Moor; stand side by side,
Come, hands off, leave your ducking, hell cannot fright,
Their spirits that do desperately fight.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: You are too rash, you are too hot,
Wild desperateness doth valour blot;
The lodging of the Kings beset,
With staring faces black as Jett,
And hearts of Iron, your deaths are vow'd
If you fly that way, therefore shrow'd,
Your body in Frier Coles gray weed,
For is't not madnesse man to bleed:
When you may scape untouch'd away,
Here's hell, here's heaven, here if you stay
You're gon, you're gon, Frier Crab and I,
Will here dance friskin whilst you flie:
Gag us, bind us, come put on
The Gags too wide, so gon, gon, gon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh! well, I'le come again, Lord Cardinall
Take you your Castle, I'le to Portugall:
I vow I'le come again, and if I do:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Black Devill I'le conjure you.

div.head: Scena. V.
div.stage: To the Friers making a noise, gagg'd and bound, Enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, and other Moors, all with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: GUard all the passages, Zarack stand there,
There Baltazar, there you, the Friers,
Where have you plac'd the Friers?

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: My Lord a noise.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: The Friers are gagg'd and bound.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: 'Tis Phil. and the Cardinal, shoot; hah stay!
Unbind them; where's Mendoza, and the Prince.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Sancta Maria who can tell:
By Peters keys they bound us well,
And having crack'd our shaven crowns,
They have escap'd you in our gowns.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Escap'd; escap'd away? I am glad, it's good,
I would their arms may turn to Eagles wings,
To flye us swift, as time sweet air give way,
Winds leave your two and thirty pallaces,
And meeting all in one, join all your might,
To give them speedy and a prosperous flight,
Escap'd Friers, which way?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: This way.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Good: Alas; what sin is't to shed innocent blood;
For look you holy men, it is the King;
The King, the King, see Friers sulphury wrath
Having once entred into Royall brests:
Mark how it burns, the Qu. Philip's mother;
Oh! most unnaturall, will have you two
Divulge abroad that hee's a bastard. Oh!
Will you doo't.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: What says my brother Frier?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Princes love is balm, their wrath a fire:

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: 'Tis true, but yer I'le publish no such thing;
What fool would lose his soul, to please a King?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Keep there, good there, yet for it wounds my soul,
To see the miserablest wretch to bleed.
I counsell you (in care unto your lives)
T'obey the mother Queen, for by my life
I thinke shee has been prick'd, her conscience
Oh! it has stung her, for some fact misdon,
She would not else disgrace her selfe and son
Doo't therefore, harke, shee'l work your deaths else, hate
Bred in a woman is insatiate.
Doo't Friers.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Brother Cole? Zeal sets me in a flame,
I'le doo't.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: And I,
His basenesse wee'l proclaim

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do, and be damn'd; Zarack and Baltazar.
Dog them at th' hee'ls, and when their poisonous breath
Hath scattered this infection, on the hearts
Of credulous Spaniards, here reward them thus,
Slaves too much trusted do grow dangerous;
Why this shall feed,
And fat suspition, and my pollicy
I'le ring through all the Court, this loud alarum:
That they contriv'd the murder of the King,
The Qu. and me; and being undermin'd,
To scape the blowing up, they fled. Oh good!
There, there, thou there, cry treason; each one take
A severall door, your cries my musick make.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Where's the King? treason persues him:

div.stage: Enter Alvero in his shirt, his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Where's the sleepy Qu. Rise, rise, and arm, against the hand of treason.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Whence comes this sound of treason?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who frights our quiet slumbers,
sp.stage: Enter King in his shirt, his sword drawn.
sp.l: With this heavy noise:

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Was it a dream? or did the sound
sp.stage: Enter Queen in her night attire.
sp.l: Of monster treason call me from my rest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who rais'd this rumour Eleaz. you?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I did my Liege, and still continue it,
Both for your safety, and mine own discharge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whence coms the ground then?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: from the Cardinall,
And the young Prince, who bearing in his mind
The true Idea of his late disgrace,
In putting him from the Protectorship,
And envying the advancment of the Moor
Determined this night to murder you;
And for your Highnesse lodg'd within my Castle,
They would have laid the murder on my head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Cardinall, and my Brother bring them forth
Their lives shall answer this ambitious practice.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Alas my Lord it is impossible,
For when they saw I had discovered them
They train'd two harmlesse Friers to their lodgings;
Disrob'd them, gagg'd them, bound'em 〈◊〉 two posts,
And in their habits did escape the Castle.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That Cardinall, is all ambition,
And from him doth our Brother gather heart.

sp.speaker: Que. Mo.
sp.l: Th' ambition of th' one infects the other,
And in a word they both are dangerous;
But might your mothers counsell stand force,
I would advise you send the trusty Moor
To fetch them back, before they had seduc'd
The squint ey'd multitude from true allegiance,
And drawn them to their dangerous faction.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be so, therefore my States best prop,
Within whose bosome I durst trust my life,
Both for my safety and thine own discharge.
Fetch back those traitors, and till your return
Our self will keep your Castle.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Leige; the tongue of true obedience
Most not gainsay his Soveraigns impose,
By heaven; I will not kiss the cheek of sleep,
Till I have fetch'd those traitors to the Court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why; this sorts right, he gon; his beauteous wife
Shall sail into the naked arms of love.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Why, this is as it should bee, he once gon,
His wife that keeps me from his marriage bed,
Shall by this hand of mine be muthered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This storm is well nigh past the swelling clouds,
That hang so full of treason by the wind,
In awfull Majestie are scatt'red.
Then each man to his rest; good night sweet friend,
Whil'st thou persu'st the traitors that are fled,
Fernando means to warm thy marriage bed.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Many good nights, consume and dam your souls.
I know he means to Cuckold mee this night;
Yet do I know no means to hinder it.
Besides, who know, whether the lustful King
Having my wife and Castle at command,
Will ever make surrender back again:
But if he do not, with my falchions point
I'le lance those swelling veins in which hot lust
Does keep his Revels, and with that warm blood
Where Venus's bastard coold his sweltring spleen,
Wash the disgrace from Eleazars brows.

div.head: Act. II.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: DEar Eleazar;

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: If they lock the gates
I'le tosse a ball of wild-fire o're the walls.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Husband, sweet husband:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Or else swim o're the moat,
And make a breach through the flinty sides
Of the rebellious walls:

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Hear me, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Or undermine the chamber where they lie,
And by the violent strength of gunpowder,
Blow up the Castle, and th' incestuous couch,
In which lust wallows; but my labouring thoughts,
Wading too deep in bottomless extreams;
Do drown themselvs in their own stratagems.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Sweet husband! dwell not upon circumstance,
When weeping sorrow like an Advocate
Importunes you for aid; look in mine eyes
There you shall see dim grief swimming in tears,
Invocating succor. Oh succor!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Succor. Zounds for what?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To shield me from Fernando's unchast love,
Who with uncessant praiers importun'd me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: To lie with you I know't.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Then seek some means how to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: 'Tis possible; for to the end that his unbridled lust
Might have more free accesse unto thy bed,
This night he hath enjoined me
To fetch back Philip and the Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Then this ensuing night shall give an end
To all my sorrows, for before foul lust
Shall soil the fair complexion of mine honour,
This hand shall rob Maria of her life.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Not so dear soul, for in extremities
Choose out the least, and ere the hand of death
Should suck this Ivorie pallace of thy life:
Imbrace my counsell, and receive this poison
Which in the instant he attempts thy love,
Then give it him: do, do,
Do poison him, he gon, thou'rt next;
Be sound in resolution; and farewell;
By one, and one, I'le ship you all to hell.
Spain I will drown thee with thine own proud blood,
Then make an ark of carcasses farewell.
Revenge and I will sail in blood to hell.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Poison the King, Alas my trembling hand
Would let the poison fall, and through my cheeks
Fear suted in a bloodless livery,
Would make the world acquainted with my guilt,
But thanks prevention, I have found a means
Both to preserve my Royall Soveraignes life,
And keep my self a true and Loyall wife.

div.trailer: The end of the second Act.

div.head: Scena I.
div.stage: Enter Queen Mother, with a Torch, solus.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: FAir eldest child of love, thou spotlesse night,
Empresse of silence, and the Queen of sleep;
Who with thy black cheeks pure complexion,
Mak'st lovers eyes enamour'd of thy beauty:
Thou art like my Moor, therefore will I adore thee,
For lending me this opportunity,
Oh with the soft skin'd Negro! heavens keep back
The saucy staring day from the worlds eye,
Untill my Eleazar make return;
Then in his Castle shall he find his wife,
Transform'd into a strumpet by my son;
Then shall he hate her whom he would not kill?
Then shall I kill her whom I cannot love?
The King is sporting with his Concubine.
Blush not my boy, be bold like me thy mother,
But their delights torture my soul like Devills,
Except her shame be seen: Wherefore awake
Christophero, Verdugo, raise the Court,
Arise you Peers of Spain, Alvaro rise,
Preserve your country from base infamies.

div.stage: Enter severally at severall doors, with lights and Rapiers drawn, Alvero, Roderigo, and Christophero, with others.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Who rais'd these exclamations through the Court?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Sheath up your Swords, you need not swords, but eyes
To intercept this treason.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What's the treason?
Who are traitors? ring the larum bell;
Cry arm through all the City; once before
The horrid sound of treason did affright
Our sleeping spirits.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Stay, you need not cry arm
Arm, for this black deed
Works treason to your King, to me; to you,
To Spain, and all that shall in Spain ensue.
This night Maria (Eleazars wife)
Hath drawn the King by her Lascivious looks
Privately to a banquet, I unseen
Stood and beheld him in him in her lustfull arms.
Oh God! shall bastards wear Spains Diadem?
If you can kneel to basenesse, vex them not;
If you disdain to kneel, wash of this blot.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Lets break into the chamber and surprize her?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Oh miserable me! do, do, break in,
My Country shall not blush at my childs sin.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Delay is nurse to danger, follow me,
Come you and witnesse to her villany.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Haplesse Alvero, how art thou undone,
In a light daughter, and a stubborn son.

div.head: Scena II.
div.stage: Enter King with his Rapier drawn in one hand, leading Maria seeming affrighted in th' other.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: OH! kill me ere you stain my chastity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My hand holds death, but love sits in mine eye,
Exclaim not dear Maria, do but hear me;
Though thus in dead of night as I do now
The lustfull Tarquin stole to the chast bed
Of Collatines fair wife, yet shalt thou be
No Lucrece, nor thy King a Romane slave,
To make rude villanie thine honours grave.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Why from my bed have you thus frighted me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To let the view a bloody horrid Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Begin it then, I'le gladly loose my life,
Rather then be an Emperours Concubine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By my high birth I swear thou shalt be none,
The Tragedy I'le write with my own hand,
A King shall act it, and a King shall dye;
Except sweet mercies beam shine from thine eye.
If this affright thee it shall sleep for ever,
If still thou hate me, thus this Noble blade,
This Royall purple temple shall invade.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: My husband is from hence, for his sake spare me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy husband is no Spaniard, thou art one,
So is Fernando, then for countries sake
Let mee not spare thee, on thy husbands face
Eternall night in gloomy shades doth dwel;
But I'le look on thee like the guilded Sun,
When to the west his fiery horses run.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: True, true, you look on me with Sun set eyes,
For by beholding you my glory dies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call me thy morning then, for like the morn,
In pride Maria shall through Spain be born.
This musick I prepar'd thine ears,
Loue mee and thou shalt hear no other sounds,
Lo here's a banquet set with mine own hands;
Love me, and thou shalt feast thee like a Queen:
I might command thee being thy Soveraign;
But love me and I'le kneel and sue to thee,
And circle this white forehead with the Crown
Of Castile, Portugall, and Arragon,
And all those petty Kingdoms which do bow
Their tributarie knees to Philip's heir.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I cannot love you whilst my husband lives:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'le send him to the wars, and in the front
Of some maine army shall he nobly dye.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I cannot love you if you murder him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For thy sake then, I'le call a Parlament
And banish by a law all Moors from Spain.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I'le wander with him into banishment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be death for any Negroes hand,
To touch the beauty of a Spanish dame.
Come, come, what needs such cavells with a King?
Night blinds all Jealous eyes, and we may play,
Carowse that bole to me, I'le pledg all this,
Being down, we'l make it more sweet with a kiss.
Begin, I'le lock all doors, begin Spains Queen,
Loves banquet is most sweet, when 'tis least seen.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Oh thou conserver of my honours life!
Instead of poisoning him, drown him in sleep,
Because I'le quench the flames of wild desire,
I'le drink this off, let fire conquer loves fire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Were love himselfe in reall substance here,
Thus would I drink him down, let your sweet strings,
Speak lowder (pleasure is but a slave to Kings)
In which love swime. Maria kiss thy King,
Circle me in this ring of Ivory.
Oh! I grow dull, and the cold hand of sleep
Hath thrust his Icie fingers in my brest,
And made a frost within me; sweet, one kiss
To thaw this deadnesse that congeales my soul.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Your Majestie hath overwatch'd your self,
He sleeps already, not the sleep of death;
But a sweet slumber, which the powerfull drugg
Instill'd through all his spirits. Oh! bright day
Bring home my dear Lord, ere his King awake,
Else of his unstain'd bed he'l shipwrack make.

div.stage: Enter Oberon, and Fairyes dancing before him, and musick with them.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Oh me! what shapes are these?

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.l: Stay, stay, Maria.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: My Soveraign Lord awake, save poor Maria.

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.l: He cannot save thee, save that pain,
Before he wake thou shalt be slain;
His mothers hand shall stop thy breath,
Thinking her own son is done to death:
And she that takes away thy life,
Does it to be thy husbands wife.
Adieu Maria, we must hence,
Imbrace thine end with patience;
Elves and Fairyes make no stand,
Till you come in Fairy Land.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Fairyes or Divels, whatsoe're you be,
Thus will I hide me from your company.

div.head: Scena. III.
div.stage: To her, Enter Queen Mother suddainly, with Alvaro, and Roderigo, with Rapiers.

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: LAy hold upon the strumpet, where's the King?
Fernando, son; ah me your King is dead!
Lay hand upon the murdresse.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Imperious Queen, I am as free from murder as thy self,
Which I will prove, if you will here me speak:
The King is living.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: If he liv'd his breath would beat within his breast.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: The life he leads, Maria thou shalt soon participate.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Oh father save me!

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: thou'rt no child of mine, had'st thou been owner of Alvero's spirit.
Thy heart would not have entertain'd a thought
That had converst with murder: yet mine eyes
(Howe're my tongue want words) brim full with tears,
Intreat her further tryall.

sp.speaker: Verdugo.
sp.l: To what end: here lies her tryall: from this royall brest
Hath she stolne all comfort, all the life
Of every bosom in the Realm of Spain.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: She's both a traytor and murdress.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: I'le have her forthwith strangled.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Hear her speak.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: To heaven let her complain if she have wrong,
I murder but the murdresse of my son.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: We murder the murdresse of our King.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Ah me my child oh! Oh cease your torturing!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Heaven ope the windows, that my spotlesse soul,
Riding upon the wings of innocence,
May enter paradice, Fairyes farewell;
Fernandoes death in mine you did foretell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who calls Fernando? love, Maria, speak:
Oh! whither art thou fled? whence flow these waters
That fall like winter storms, from the drown'd eyes.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: From my Maria's death!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Maria dead?
Damn'd be the soul to hell that stop'd her breath;
Maria, Oh me who durst murder her?

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: I thought my dear Fernando had been dead,
And in my indignation murdred her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I was not dead untill you murdred me
By killing fair Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Gentle son.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ungentle mother, you a deed have done,
Of so much ruth that no succeeding age
Can ever clear you of; Oh my dear love,
Yet heavens can witnesse thou wert never mine:
Spains wonder was Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Sweet have done:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have done! for what, for shedding zealous tears
Over the tomb of virtues chastitie;
You cry have done, now I am doing good,
But cri'd do on, when you were shedding blood:
Have you done mother; yes, yes, you have done,
That which will undo your unhappy son.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: These words become you not my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These words become not me, no more it did
Become you Lords to be mute standers by,
When lustfull fury ravish'd chastity.
It ill becomes mee to lament her death,
But it became you well to stop her breath:
Had she been fair and not so virtuous,
This deed had not been halfe so impious.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: But she was fair in virtue, virtuous fair, oh me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh me! she was true honours heir.
Hence beldame from my presence, all flye hence,
You are all murderers, com poor innocence,
Clasp thy cold hand in mine, for here I'le lye,
And since I liv'd for her, for her I'l die.

div.head: Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Eleazar with a Torch and Rapier drawn.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: BAr up my Castle Gates; fire and confusion
Shall girt these Spanish Currs; was I for this,
Sent to raise power against a fugitive:
To have my wife deflowr'd. Zounds where's my wife,
My slaves cry out, she's dallying with the King?
Stand by, where is your King? Eleazars bed shall
Scorn to be an Emperours brothelrie.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Be patient Eleazar, here's the King,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Patience and I am foes, where's my Maria?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Here is her haplesse coarse that was Maria.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here lies Maria's body, here her grave,
Her dead heart in my breast a tomb shal have.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Now by the proud complexion of my cheeks,
Tan'e from the kisses of the amorous sun;
Were he ten thousand Kings that slew my love,
Thus shou'd my hand (plum'd with revenges wings)
Requite mine own dishonour, and her death.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Ah me! my son.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The King is murdred, lay hold on the damn'd traitor.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: In his brest that dares but dart a finger at the Moor,
I'le bury this Sharp steel yet reeking warm,
With the unchast blood of that lecher King,
That threw my wife in an untimely grave.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: She was my daughter and her timelesse grave
Did swallow down my joies as deep as yours:
But thus.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: But what? bear injuries that can,
I'le wear no forked crest.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Damn this black feind, crie treason through the Court.
The King is murdred.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He that first opes his lips, I'le drive his words
Down his wide throat upon my rapiers point.
The King is murdred and I'le answer it;
I am dishonour'd, and I will revenge it.
Bend not your dangerous weapons at my brest:
Thinke where you are, this Castle is the Moors,
You are inviron'd with a wall of flint.
The Gates are lock'd, Purcullesses let down
If Eleaz. spend one drop of blood,
sp.stage: Zarack and Baltazar above with Calivers.
sp.l: On those high turret tops my slaves stand arm'd,
And shall con found your souls with murdring shot.
Or if you murder me, yet under ground
A villain that for me will dig to hell,
Stands with a burning limstock in his fist,
Who firing gunpowder up in the air,
Shall fling your torn and mangled carcasses.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Oh! sheath your weapons, though my son be slain,
Yet save your selvs, choose a new Soveraign.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Prince Philip is our Soveraign, choose him King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Prince Philip shall not be my Soveraign,
Philip's a bastard, and Fernando's dead;
Mendoza sweats to wear Spains Diadem,
Philip hath sworn confusion to this Realm,
They both are up in arms, warrs flames do shine
Like lightning in the air, wherefore my Lords
Look well on Eleazar; value me not by my sun-burnt
Cheek, but by my birth; nor by
My birth, but by my losse of blood,
Which I have sacrificed in Spains defence.
Then look on Philip, and the Cardinall:
Look on those gaping currs, whose wide throats
Stand stretch'd wide open like the gates of death,
To swallow you, your country, children, wives.
Philip cries fire and blood, the Cardinall
Cries likewise fire and blood, I'le quench those flames,
The Moor cries blood and fire, and that shall burn
Till Castile like proud Troy to Cinders turn.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Lay by these Ambages, what seeks the Moor?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A Kingdom, Castiles crown.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Peace divell for shame.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Peace doting Lord for shame, Oh miserie!
When Indian slaves thirst after Empery;
Princes and Peers of Spain wee are beset,
With horror on each side; you deny him,
Death stands at all our backs, we cannot flye him.
Crown Philip King, The Crown upon his head,
Will prove a fiery Meteor, Warr and vengeance
And desolation will invade our land,
Besides Prince Philip is a bastard born.
Oh! give mee leave to blush at mine own shame;
But I for love to you, love to fair Spain,
Choose rather to rip up a Queens disgrace,
Then by concealing it to set the Crown
Upon a bastards head. Wherefore my Lords
By my consent crown that proud Blackamore,
Since Spains bright glory must so soon grow dim;
Since it must end, let it end all in him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eleazar shall be King.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Oh treachery! have you so soon rac't out Fernando's love;
So soon forgot the duty of true Peers;
So soon, so soon buried a mothers name,
That you will crown him King that slew your King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Will you hear him or me, who shall be King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eleazar shall be Castiles Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Do, do; make hast to crown him! Lords adieu.
Here hell must be when the Divel governs you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By heavens great Star, which Indians do adore,
But that I hate to hear the giddy world;
Shame that I waded to a Crown through; blood,
I'de not disgest his pills, but since my Lords
You have chosen Eleazar for your King?
Invest me with a generall applause.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Live Eleazar, Castiles Royall King.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: A villain and a base born fugitive.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: A bloody tyrant, an usurping slave.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thanks to you all, 'tis not the Spanish Crown
That Eleazar strives for, but Spains peace.
Amongst you I'le divide her Empery;
Christofero shall wear Granado's Crown;
To Roderigo I'le give Arragon:
Naples, Navar and fair Jerusalem,
I'le give to other three, and then our vice Roys,
Shall Shine about our bright Castilian crown,
As stars about the Sun. Cry all, arm, arm;
Prince Philip and the Cardinall do ride
Like Jove in thunder, in a storme we'l meet them;
Go levy powers, if any man must fall,
My death shall first begin the funerall.

div.head: Scena. V.
div.stage: Enter Zarack and Baltazar with Calivers.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: IS thy cock ready, and thy powder dry.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My cock stands pearching, like a cock o'the game;
With a red cole for his crest instead of a colme;
And for my powder, 'tis but touch & take.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: I have tickling geer too, anon I'le cry here I have it,
And yonder I see it; But Zarack is't policie for us
To kill these bald-pates.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Is't pollicy for us to save our selves,
If they live, we die. Is't not wisdom then
To send them to heaven, rather then be sent our selves;
Come you black slave, be resolute. This way they come,
Here they will stand, and yonder wil I stand.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: And in yonder hole I.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Our amiable faces cannot be seen, if we keep close:
Therefore hide your cocks head, left his burning cocks-comb betray us.
But soft, which of the two shall be thy white.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: That black villain Frier Cole.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I shall have a sharp piece of service.
Frier Crab shall be my man.
Farewell and be resolute.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Zounds Zarack I shall never have the heart to doo't.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: You rogue think who commands, Eleazar.
Who shall rise Baltazar?
Who shall die, a louzy Frier?
Who shall live our good Lord and Master?
The Negro King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Cole, thou art but a dead man,
And shall turn to ashes.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Crab, here's that shall make vinegar of thy carcasse.

div.stage: Enter Crab and Cole, two Friers, with a rout of Stinkards following them.

sp.speaker: Frier Crab.
sp.l: I brother 'tis best, so now we have drawn them to a head,
We'l begin here i'th market place.
Tut so long as we be commanded by the Mother Queen.
We'l say her son is a bastard, and he were ten Philips.

sp.speaker: F. Cole.
sp.l: Take you one market form, I'le take another.

sp.speaker: F. Crab.
sp.l: No, Gods so; we must both keep one form.

sp.speaker: F. Cole.
sp.l: I in oration, but not in station mount, mount?
Well my masters, you know him not so well as I; on my word
Frier Crab is a sowr fellow:
Yet he may utter sweet doctrine by your leave; but what
Think you of Frier Cole?
He all fire, and he be kindled once a hot Catholick.
And you mark him, he has a zealous nose,
And richly inflam'd.
Peace you Rogues, now they begin.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Incipe Frater?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Non ego Domine.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Nec ego.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Quare?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Quia?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Quaeso,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here's a queazy beginning me thinks; silence, silence.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Brethren, Citizens, and market-folks of Sivell.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Well beloved and honoured Castilians.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: It is not unknown to you!

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: I am sure you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: How villanous and strong?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: How monstruous and huge?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: The faction of Prince Philip is;

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Philip that is a bastard:

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Philip that is a dastard.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Philip that kill'd your King.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Onely to make himself King.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: And by Gads blessed Lady you are all damn'd, and you suffer it.
Frier Cole says true, he speaks out of the heat of his zeal;
Look how he glows.
Well Frier Crab for my money, he has set my teeth an edge
Against this bastard.
Oh! his words are like Vergis, to whet a mans stomach.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Silence, silence.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Now contrariwise.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Your Noble King the Moor.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Is a valiant Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: An honourable Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A fair black Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: A friend to Castilians.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Champion for Castilians.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: A man fit to be King.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: If he were not born down by him that would be King,
Who (as I said before) is a bastard, and no King.
What think you my masters? do you mark his words well.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Further compare them together.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: S'blood, there's no comparison between them.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Nay, but hear us good Country men.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hear Frier Cole, hear Frier Cole.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Set that bastard and Eleazar together:
How? mean you, by the ears.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: No, but compare them.

sp.speaker: Colê.
sp.l: Do but compare them.
Zounds, we say again comparisons are odious.
But say on, say on.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, treason, every man shift for himself.
This is Philips treason. Arm, Arm, Arm.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: ZArack and Baltazar, are they dispatch'd?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: We saw'em sprawl, and turn up the white of the eye.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: So shall they perish, that lay countermines;
To erosse our high designments: by their habits,
The Cardinall and Philip scap'd our nets.
And by your hands they tasted our revenge.
Here come the Queen, away! under our wings,
You shall stand safe, and brave the proudest Kings.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo
sp.l: Oh! flie my Eleazar, save thy lite.
Else point a guard about thee, the mad people
Tempestuous like the Sea run up and down
Some crying kill the bastard, some the Moor;
Some cry, God save King Philip; and some cry,
God save the Moor; some others, he shall die.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Are these your fears, thus blow them into air.
I rushe amongst the thickest of their crowds,
And with a countenance Majestical,
Like the Imperious Sun disperst their clouds;
I have persum'd the rankness of their breath,
And by the magick of true eloquence,
Transform'd this many headed Cerberus,
This py'd Camelion, this beast multitude,
Whose power consists in number, pride in threats;
Yet melt like snow when Majestie shines forth
This heap of fools, who crowding in huge, swarms,
Stood at our Court gates like a heap of dung,
Reeking and shouting out contagious breath
of power to poison all the elements;
This Wolf I held by'th ears, and made him tame,
And made him tremble at the Moors great name.
No, we must combate with a grimmer foe,
That damn'd Mendoza over-turns our hopes.
He loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.p:
By his secret Letters he hath intreated
me in some disguise to leave the Court, and fly into his arms.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The world cannot devize a stratagem
Sooner to throw confusion on his pride:
Subscribe to his desires, and in dead night
Steal to his Castle, swear to him his love
Hath drawn you thither; undermine his soul,
And learn what villanies are there laid up,
Then for your pleasure walk to take the air:
Near to the Castle I'le in ambush lie,
And seem by force to take you prisoner;
This done, I have a practice plotted here,
Shall rid him of his life, and us of fear:
About it madam, this is all in all;
We cannot stand unlesse Mendoza fall.

div.head: Scena. I.
div.stage: Enter Emanuel King of Portugal, Prince Philip, Mendoza, Alvaro, with Drums and Souldiers marching.

sp.speaker: King Port.
sp.l: POor Spain, how is the body of thy peace
Mangled and torn by an ambitious Moor!
How is thy Prince and Counsellors abus'd,
And trodden under the base foot of scorn:
Wrong'd Lords, Emanuel of Portugal partakes
A falling share in all your miseries:
And though the tardy-hand of slow delay
With-held us from preventing your mishaps;
Yet shall revenge dart black confusion
Into the bosom of that damned fiend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But is it possible our Mother Queen
Should countenance his ambition.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Her advice is as a Steers-man to direct his course.
Besides, as we by circumstance have learnt,
She means to marry him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then here upon my knees
I pluck allegiance from her; all that love
Which by innative duty I did owe her,
Shall henceforth be converted into hate.
This will confirm the worlds opinion
That I am base born, and the damned Moor
Had interest in my birth, this wrong alone
Gives new fire to the cinders of my rage:
I may be well transformed from what I am,
When a black divel is husband to my dam.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Prince, let thy rage give way to patience,
And set a velvet brow upon the face
Of wrinkled anger, our keen swords,
Must right these wrongs, and not light airy words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yet words may make the edge of rage more sharp,
And whet a blunted courage with revenge.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Here's none wants whetting, for our keen resolves
Are steel'd unto the back with double wrongs;
Wrongs that would make a handlesse man take arms;
Wrongs that would make a coward resolute.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Why then join all our severall wrongs in one,
And from these wrongs assume a firm resolv,
To send this divell to damnation.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hear the sound of his approaching march,
Stand fair; Saint Jaques for the right of Spain.

div.stage: To them, Enter the Moor, Roderigo, Christofero, with drums, colours, and souldiers, marching bravely.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Bastard of Spain?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou true stamp'd son of hell,
Thy pedigree is written in thy face.

div.stage: Alarum, and a Battail, the Moor prevails: All Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: MOve forward, with your main battalion,
Or else all is lost.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I will not move a foot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: S'heart, wil you lose the day.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: You lose your witts,
You're mad, it is no pollicy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You lye.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Lye?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lye, a pox upon't Cardinall com on,
Second the desperate vanguard which is mine,
And where I'le dye or win, follow my sword
The bloody way I lead it, or by heaven
I'le play the Devill, and mar all, we'l turn our backs
Upon thee Moors, and set on thee; I thee,
Thee Cardinall, s'heart thee.

sp.speaker: Cardi.
sp.l: Your desperate arm
Hath almost thrust quite through the heart of hope;
Our fortunes lye a bleeding by your rash and violent
On set.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh! oh! s'life, s'foot, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: We will not hazard all upon one cast.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You will not?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Coward.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: By deeds I'le try,
Whether your venemous tongue says true, fare well.
Courage shines both in this, and policy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To save thy skin whole, that's thy policy;
You whorson fat-chopt guts. I'le melt away
That larded body by the heat of fight,
Which I'le compel thee to, or else by flying;
To work which I'le give way to the proud foe,
Whilst I stand laughing to behold thee run.
Cardinall I'le do't, I'le do't, a Moor, a Moor,
Philip cries a Moor, holla! ha! whoo!

sp.speaker: King of Port.
sp.l: Prince, Philip, Philip,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here, plague where's the Moor.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: The Moor's a Devill, never did horrid feind
Compel'd by som Magicians mighty charm,
Break through the prisons of the solid earth,
With more strange horror, then this Prince of hell,
This damned Negro Lyon-like doth rush,
Through all, and spite of all knit opposition.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Puh! puh! where? Where? I'le meet him, where? you mad me.
'Tis not his arm,
That acts such wonders, but our cowardise,
This Cardinall, oh! this Cardinall is a slave.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.l: Sound a retreat, or else the day is lost;

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'le beat that dog to death, that sounds; retreat.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'le tear his heart out, that dares name but Sound.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Sound a retreat.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who's that? you tempt my sword Sir.
Continue this alarum, fight pell mell?
Fight, kill, be damn'd? this fat-back Coward Cardinal,
Lies heavie on my shoulders; this, I this
Shall fling him off: Sound a retreat! Zounds, you mad me.
Ambition plumes the Moor, whilst black despair
Offering to tear from him the Diadem
Which he usurps, make, him to cry at all,
And to act deeds beyond astonishment;
But Philip is the night that darks his glories,
This swords yet reeking with his Negro's blood,
Being grasp't by equity, and this strong arm
Shall through and through.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: From before mee;
Stay, stand, stand fast, fight? A Moor, a Moor.

div.head: Scena. III.
div.stage: To them enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, Roderigo, Christofero, and others, they fight, Moors are all beat in, Exeunt omnes, manet Eleazar weary; staies, a Moor lies slain.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: OH for more work, more souls to post to hell;
That I might pile up Charons boat so full,
Untill it topple o're, Oh 'twould be sport
To see them sprawl through the black slimy lake.
Ha, ha; there's one going thither, sirrah, you,
You slave, who kill'd thee? how he grins! this breast,
Had it been tempered, and made proof like mine,
It never would have been a mark for fools
To hit afar off with their dastard bullets.
But thou didst well, thou knew'st I was thy Lord;
And out of love and duty to me here,
Where I fell weary, thou laidst down thy self
To bear me up, thus: God a-mercy slave.
A King for this shall give thee a rich grave.
