div.stage: As he sits down, enter Philip with a broken sword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'le wear thee to the pommel, but I'le finde
The subject of mine honour and revenge.
Moor 'tis for thee I seek; Come now, now take me
At good advantage: speak, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fate and revenge I thank you rise.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Leave and live.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Villain, it is Philippe that bids rise.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It had been good for thee to have hid thy name.
Forthe discovery, like to a dangerous charm,
Hurts him that finds it, wherefore do's those blood hounds
Thy rage and valour chase me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: With that! what a blunt axe? think'st thou I'le let
Thy fury take a full blow at this head,
Having these arms, be wise; go change thy weapon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh, Sir!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le stay thy coming.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: thou't be damn'd first.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: By all our Indian gods.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Puh, never swear;
Thou know'st 'tis for a kingdome which we fight;
And for that who'l not venture to hellgates.
Come Moor, I am arm'd with more then compleat steel,
The justice of my quarrel: when I look
Upon my Fathers wrongs, my brothers wounds,
My mothers infamie, Spains miserie,
And lay my finger her, Oh! 'tis too dull,
To let out blood enough to quench them all.
But when I see your face, and know what fears.
Hang on thy troubled soul, like leaden weights,
To make it sink; I know this fingers touch
Has strenght to throw thee down, I know this iron
Is sharp and long enough to reach that head
Fly not divill, if thou do?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: How fly; Oh bast!

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Come then

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay Philip, whosoe're begat thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why slave, a King begat me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: May be so.
But I'le be sworn thy mother was a Queen;
For her sake will I kill thee nobly:
Fling me thy sword, there's mine, I scorn to strike
A man disarm'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For this dishonoring me
I'le give thee one stab more.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le run away,
Unlesse thou change that weapon, or take mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: S'heart, stay, and if you dare,
Do as I do, oppose thy naked breast
Against this poniard; see, here's this for thine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I am for thee Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, nay take more ground,
That with a full career thou maist strike home.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: thou't run away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: thou't run away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith, I will, but first on this I'le bear
Thy panting heart, thy head upon thy spear.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come.

div.stage: Enter on both sides, Cardinall, and King of Portugal, on the one side, and Moors on the other side.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Side upon the Moors.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Side upon the Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold Cardinall, strike not any of our side,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hold Moors, strike not any of our side,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: wee two will close this battail.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come, agreed.
Stand armies and give aim, whil'st wee two bleed.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: With poniards; 'tis too desperate, dear Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away, have at the Moor, s'heart let me come?

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Be arm'd with manly weapons, 'tis for slaves,
To dig their own and such unworthy graves.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I am for thee any way, thus, or see thus,
Here try the vigour of thy sinewy arm,
The day is ours already, brainless heads
And bleeding bodyes like a crown do stand,
About the temples of our victory.
Yet Spaniards if you dare we'l fight it out,
Thus man to man alone, I'le first begin,
And conquer, or in blood wade up toth' chin.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let not a weapon stir, but his and mine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nor on this side, conquest in blood shall shine.

div.stage: Alarum. They fight a Combate, The Moor is struck down, which his side seeing, step all in and rescue him; The rest joine and drive in the Moors. Alarum continuing, Spaniards and Moors with drums and colours flye over the stage, persued by Philip, Cardinall, King Port. And others. Enter Zarack Christofero, and Eleazar at severall doors.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Where is our Soveraign?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What news brings Zarack and Christofero?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Oh flye my Lord! flye; for the day is lost.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: There are three hundred and odd days in a year,
And cannot we lose one of them, com fight.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: The Lords have left us, and the souldiers faint,
You are round beset with proud fierce enemies;
Death cannot be prevented but by flight?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He shall Christofero I have yet left,
One stratagem that in despite of fate,
Shal turn the wheel of war about once more,
The Mother Queen hath all this while sate sadly,
Within our tent, expecting to whose bosom,
White winged peace and victory will flie,
Her have I us'd as a fit property,
To stop this dangerous current; her have I sent,
Arm'd with loves magick to inchant the Cardinall;
And bind revenge down with resistlesse charms.
By this time does she hang about his neck,
And by the witchcraft of a cunning kiss;
Has she disarm'd him, hark, they sound
She has prevail'd, a womans tongue and eye;
Are weapons stronger then Artillery.

div.head: Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Cardinall, Queen Mother. Souldiers, drums, and colours.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: BY all those sighs which thou (like passionate tunes)
Hast often to my dull ears offered,
By all thy hopes to enjoy my roial Bed;
By all those mourning lines which thou hast sent,
Weeping in black to tell thy languishment:
By loves best richest treasure, which I swear,
I wil bestow, and which none else shal wear,
As the most pris'd Jewell, but thy selfe,
By that bright fire which flaming through thine eyes;
From thy love scorched bosom does arise.
I do conjure thee, let no churlish sound,
With wars lewd horror my desires confound;
Dear, dear Mendoza, thus I do intreat,
That stil thou would'st continue this retreat;
I'le hang upon thee till I hear thee say,
Woman prevail; or chiding, cri'st away.

sp.speaker: Card
sp.l: Is there no trick in this, forg'd by the Moor?

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: I would the Moors damnation were the ransom,
Of all that innocent blood, that has been shed
In this black day; I care not for the Moor,
Love to my kingdoms peace makes me put on
This habit of a suppliant; shall I speed?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: You shall, were it to have my bosom bleed:
I have no power to spare the Negroes head,
When I behold the wounds which his black hand
Has given mine honour: but when I look on you,
I have no power to hate him, since your breath
Disolves my frozen heart, being spent for him;
In you my life must drown it self or swim,
You have prevail'd: Drum swiftly hence? call back
Our fierce pursuing troops, that run to catch
The lawrel wreath of conquest: Let it stand
A while untouch'd by any souldiers hand.
Away? stay you and guard us, where's the Moor?
I'le lose what I have got, a victors prize,
Yielding my self a prisoner to your eyes.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Mine eyes shall quickly grant you liberty,
The Moor stays my return, I'le put on wings,
And fetch him, to make peace belongs to Kings.

div.stage: As she goes out, Enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, and souldiers well arm'd, at sight of each other all draw.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Souldiers call back the drum, wee are betraid.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Moors stand upon your guard, avoid, look back.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What means this jealousie? Mendoza, Moor,
Lay by your weapons, and imbrace the fight,
Of this, and this; begets suspition,
Eleazar by my birth, he coms in peace,
Mendoza by mine honour so coms he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Discharge these souldiers then.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And these.

sp.speaker: Cardinall.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Go.

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: Soul, rejoice to see this glorious day.

div.stage: She joins them together, they imbrace.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your virtues work this wonder: I have met,
At her most dear command, whats your desires?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Peace and your honour'd arms: how loathingly
I sounded the alarums, witnesse heaven
'Twas not to strike your breast, but to let out,
The rank blood of ambition: That Philip
Makes you his ladder, and being climb'd so high
As he may reach a diadem, there you lie.
He's base begotten, that's his mothers sin.

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: God pardon it.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I, amen, but he's a bastard,
And rather then I'le kneel to him, I'le saw
My leggs off by the thighs, because I'le stand
In spite of reverence: he's a bastard, he's,
And to beat down his usurpation,
I have thrown about this thunder, but Mendoza,
The people hate him for his birth,
He only leans on you, you are his pillar;
You gone, he walks on crutches, or else falls;
Then shrink from under him, are not they
Fools, that bearing others up themselvs seem low,
Because they above sit high, why you do so.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo
sp.l: Behold this error with fixt eies.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: 'Tis true, well.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Oh! have you found it, have you smelt
The train of powder that must blow you up,
Up into air, what air? why this, a breath,
Look you, in this time may a King meet death;
An eye to't, check it, check it.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How! thus:
Steal from the heat of that incestuous blood,
Where ravisht honor, and Philippo lies;
Leave him, divide this huge and monstrous body
Of armed Spanyards into limbs thus big;
Part man from man, send every souldier home,
I'le do the like; Peace with an Olive branch
Shall flie with Dove-like wings about all Spain:
The crown which I as a good husband keep,
I will lay down upon the empty chair;
Marry you the Queen and fill it, for my part
These knees are yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Is this sound?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: From my heart.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: If you prove false.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: If I do, let fire fall—

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Upon thy head, and so it shall.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: All of my self is yours; souldiers be gone.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And that way you.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The rest I will divide:
The Lords shall be convented.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Let's meet.

sp.speaker: Qu Mo.
sp.l: Where.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here anon, this is thy winding-sheet.

div.stage: The Moor walks up and down musing.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What shape will this prodigious womb bring forth,
Which groans with such strange labour.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Why, Eleazar, art thou wrap't with joyes,
Or does thy sinking policy make to shore.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Eleazar, mad man! hear'st thou Moor.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Well, so; you turn my brains, you mar the face
Of my attempts i'th making: for this chaos,
This lump of projects, ere it be lick't over,
'Tis like a Bears conception; stratagems
Being but begot, and not got out, are like
Charg'd Cannons not discharg'd, they do no harm,
Nor good, true policy breeding in the brain
Is like a bar of Iron, whose ribs being broken,
And softned in the fire, you then may forge it
Into a sword to kill, or to a helmet, to defend life:
'Tis therefore wit to try
All fashions, ere you apparel villany;
But, but I ha suited him, fit, fit, Oh fit!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How? prethee how?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why thus; yet no, let's hence,
My heart is nearest of my counsel, yet,
I scarce dare trust my heart with't, what I do,
It shall look old, the hour wherein 'tis born,
Wonders twice seen are garments over-worn.

div.head: Act. IV.
Scena. V.
div.stage: Enter Cardinal at one door, Philippo half arm'd, and two souldiers following him with the rest of the armour: the Cardinal seeing him, turns back again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SIrrah, you Cardinal, coward, run-away:
So ho ho, what Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I am not for your lure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For that then, Oh! that it had nail'd thy heart
Up to the pommel to the earth; come, arm me,
Ha! s'foot, when all our swords were royally guilt with blood,
When with red sweat that trickled from our wounds,
Wee had dearly earn'd a victory! when hell
Had from their hinges heav'd off her iron gates
To bid the damn'd Moor and the divels enter;
Then to lose all, then to sound base retreat;
Why souldiers, hah?

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: I am glad of it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hah! glad; art glad I am dishonored?
That thou and he dishonored.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: Why? my Lord;
I am glad, that you so cleanly did come off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou hast a lean face, and a carrion heart:
A plague on him and thee too: then, s'heart then,
To crack the very hearts-strings of our Army,
To quarter it in pieces, I could tear my hair,
And in cursing spend my soul,
Cardinal; what Judas! come, wee'l fight,
Till there be left but one, if I be hee,
I'le die a glorious death.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: So will I, I hope in my bed.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Till there be but one left, my Lord, why that's now; for all our fellows are crawl'd home; some with one leg, some with ne're an arm, some with their brains beaten out, and glad they scap't so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But my dear Countrymen, you'l stick to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Stick! I my Lord, stick like Bandogs, till wee be pull'd off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That's nobly said, I'le lead you but to death,
Where I'le have greatest share, we shall win fame,
For life and that doth crown a souldiers name.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: How! to death my Lord? not I by gadelet: I have a poor wife and children at home, and if I die they beg; and do you think I'le see her go up and down the wide universal world.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For every drop of blood which thou shalt lose,
Coward I'le give thy wife a wedge of gold.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Hang him meacock, my Lord, arm your self, I'le fight for you, till I have not an eye to see the fire in my touch-hole.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be thou a King's companion, thou and I
Will dare the Cardinal, and the Moor to fight,
In single combate, shall we? hah!

sp.speaker: 2. Sould
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Wee'l beat 'em to hell gate, shall we? hah!

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Hell gate's somwhat too hot, somewhat too hot; the Porter's a knave: I'de be loath to be damn'd for my conscience; I'le knock any bodies costard, so I knock not there, my Lord; hell gates!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A pox upon such slaves.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Hang him, a peasant, my Lord, you see I am but a scrag, my Lord; my legs are not of the biggest, nor the least, nor the best that e're were stood upon, nor the worst, but they are of God's making; And for your sake, if ever we put our enemies to flight again, by Gad's lid if I run not after them like a Tiger, hoffe me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But wilt thou stand to't e're they flye? ha! wilt thou?

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Will I quoth a? by this hand, and the honour of a souldier.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And by a souldiers honour I will load thee
Whith Spanish pistolets: to have this head,
Thy face, and all thy body, stuck with scars,
Why 'tis a sight more glorious, then to see
A Lady hung with Diamonds: If thou lose
A hand, I'le send this after, if an arm,
I'le lend thee one of mine, com then lets fight.
A mangled Lame true souldier is a jem,
Worth Cesars Empire, though fools spurn at them.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.p:
Yet my Lord I ha seen lame souldiers, not worth the crutches they leant upon, hands and arms quotha? Zounds not I, I'le double my files, or stand centry, or so; But I'le be hang'd and quartred, before I'le
have my members cut off.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: And I too, hold thee there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold you both there, away you rogues, you durt,
Thus do I tread upon you, out, begon?
One valiant is an host, fight then alone.

div.stage: Enter Cardinall, Alvero, Christofero, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Prince Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For the Crown of Spain, come all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We come in love and peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But come in warr:
Bring naked swords, not lawrell boughs, in peace?
Plague on your rank peace, will you fight and cry
Down with the Moor, and then I'm yours: I'le dye,
I have a heart, two arms, a soul, a head,
I'le lay that down, I'le venture all; s'foot, all
Come tread upon me, so that Moor may fal.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By heaven that Moor shall fall.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy hand, and thine,
Give me but halfe your hearts, you have all mine,
By heaven, shall he fall?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, upon thee
Like to the ruines of a tower, to grind
Thy body into durt, traitor, and bastard,
I do arrest thee of High treason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hah!
Traitor? and bastard? and by thee? my weapons?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I, you're best do so.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alvero there's the warrant to your hands,
The prisoner is committed, Lords lets part,
Look to him on your life

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hart, hart, hart, hart,
The Devill, and his dam, the Moor, and my Mother,
Their warrant? I will not obey, Old gray beard,
Thou shalt not bee my Jayler, there's no prison,
No dungeon deep enough, no grates so strong,
That can keep in a man so mad with wrong.
What do'st thou weep?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: I would fain shed a tear,
But from mine eyes so many showrs are gon,
Grief drinks my tears so fast, that here's not one,
You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do'st thou speak to me?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And from thence to death;
I thought I should have had a tomb hung round,
With tottred colours, broken spears, I thought
My body should have fallen down, full of wounds.
But one can kill an Emperor, fool then why
Would'st thou have many? curse, be mad, and dye,

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: Scena I.
div.stage: Enter Roderigo, and Christofero; two bare-headed before them, Alvero, Cardinall alone, Zarack, and Baltazar bearing the Crown on a cushion, Eleazar next, Queen Mother after him other Lords after her, Alvero sad, meets them.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: ALvero 'tis the pleasure of the King,
Of the Queen Mother, and these honoured States,
To ease you of Philip, there's a warrant
Sent to remove him to a stronger guard.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: I thank you, you shall rid me of much care.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Sit down, and take your place!

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: If I might have the place I like best, it should be my grave.

div.stage: The Moors stand aside with the Crown, Eleazar rising, takes it!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stand in voice, reach, away!

sp.speaker: Both Moors.
sp.l: Wee are gon.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain if in this royall Court,
There sit a man, that having laid his hold,
So fast on such a jewel, and dare wear it,
In the contempt of envie as I dare,
Yet uncompell'd (as freely as poor pilgrims,
Bestow their praiers) would give such wealth away;
Let such a man step forth; what do none rise?
No, no, for Kings indeed are deities.
And who'd not (as the sun) in brightnesse shine?
To be the greatest, is to be divine:
Who among millions would not be the mightest?
To sit in God-like state, to have all eyes,
Dazled with admiration, and all tongues
Showing lowd Praiers, to rob every heart
Of love, to have the strength of every arm.
A Soveraigns name, why 'tis a Soveraign charm.
This glory round about me hath thrown beams,
I have stood upon the top of fortunes wheel,
And backward turn'd the Iron screw of fate,
The destinies have spun a silken thread
About my life, yet Noble Spaniards see?
Hoc tantum tanti, thus I cast aside
The shape of Majestie and on my knee,
sp.stage: Kneels: the Cardinall fetches the Crown and sets it on the chair.
sp.l: To this Imperiall State lowly resigne,
This usurpation, wiping off your tears,
Which stuck so hard upon me, let a hand
A right, and royall hand take up this wreath,
And guard it, right is of it self most strong,
No kingdom got by cunning can stand long.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Proceed to new election of a King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay Peers of Spain, if young Philippo,
Be Philips son, then is he Philips heir,
Then must his Royall name be set in gold,
Philip is then the Diamond to that ring;
But if he be a bastard, here's his seat,
For basenesse has no gall, till it grow great.
First therefore let him blood, if he must bleed,
Yet in what vein you strike him, best take heed:
The Portugall's his friend, you saw he came
At holding up a finger, arm'd; this peace
Rid hence his dangerous friendship, he's at home,
But when he hears, that Philip is ty'd up,
Yet hears not why, he'l catch occasions lock,
And on that narrow bridg make shift to lead
A scrambling army through the heart of Spain,
Look to't being in, he'l hardly out again.
Therefore first prove, and then proclaim him bastard.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: How shall we prove it?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He that put him out to making,
I am sure can tell, if not,
Then she that shap'd him can, here's the Queen Mother
Being prick'd in conscience, and preferring Spain,
Before her own respect, will name the man,
If he be noble & a Spaniard born, hee'l hide,
The apparent scarrs of their infamies
With the white hand of marriage; that and time,
Will eat the blemish off, say? shall it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall dye.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Death is too easie for such villany.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall dye.
I would he might, I know my self am clear
As is the new born Infant. Madam stand forth,
Behold to speak, shame in the grave wants sence:
Heaven with sins greatest forfeits can dispence.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Would I were covered with the vail of night,
You might not see red shame sit on my cheecke;
But being Spains common safety stands for truth,
Hiding my weeping eyes, I blush, and say;
Philippo's father sits here.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Here! name him?

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: The Lord Mendoza did beget that son,
Oh! let not this dishonour further run?

sp.speaker: Alve,
sp.l: What Cardinall Mendoza?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Yes, yes, even hee

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I Philips father?—

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: Nay! deny me not?
Now may a kingdom and my love be got.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Those eyes and tongue bewitch me, shame lie here;
That love has sweetest tast that is bought dear.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: What answers Lord Mendoza to the Queen?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I confesse guilty, Philip is my son,
Her Majestie hath nam'd the time and place.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To you, but not to us, go forward Madam.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Within the circle of twice ten years since,
Your deceast King made warr in Barbarie,
Won Tunis, conquered Fesse, and hand to hand,
Slew great Abdela, King of Fesse, and father
To that Barbarian Prince.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I was but young, but now methinks
I see my fathers wounds, poor Barbaria!
No more.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: In absence of my Lord mourning his want,
To me alone, being in my private walk,
I think at Salamanca; I, 'twas there;
Enters Mendoza under shew of shrift,
Threatens my death if I deni'd his lust,
In fine by force he won me to his will,
I wept, and cri'd for help, but all in vain;
Mendoza there abus'd the bed of Spain.

sp.speaker: E'eaz
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, that saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Alve
sp.l: Why did not you complain of this vile act?

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: Alas! I was alone, young, full of fear;
Bashful, and doubtfull of my own defame;
Knowing King Philip rash and jealous,
I hid his sins, thinking to hide my shame.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: What says the Cardinall?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Such a time there was;
'Tis past, I'le make amends with marriage,
And satisfie with Trentalls, dirges, praiers,
The offended spirit of the wronged King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, that saucy slave shall die;
Oh! 'twould seem best, it should be thus Mendoza:
She to accuse, I urge, and both conclude,
Your marriage like a comick interlude.
Lords will you hear this hatefull sin confest?
And not impose upon the ravisher death,
The due punishment, oh! it must be so.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: What does the Queen desire?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Justice, revenge,
On vile Mendoza for my ravishment:
I kiss the cold earth with my humbl'd knees,
From whence I will not rise, till some just hand,
Cast to the ground the Traitor Cardinall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Stand forth Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Swells your heart so high?
Down Lecher; if you wil not stand, then lie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You have betrai'd me, by my too much trust,
I never did this deed of Rape and Lust.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Your tongue confest it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: True, I was intic'd.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Intic'd? do you beleeve that?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Justice Lords! sentence the Cardinall for
His hatefull sin.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: We will assemble all the States of Spain,
And as they Judge, so Justice shall be done.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A guard! to prison with the Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Dam'd slave my tongue shall go at liberty
To curse thee, ban that strumpet; Doggs keep off.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hist, hist, on, on.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I cannot brook his sight.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: You must to prison, and bee patient.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Weep'st thou Alvero? all struck dumb? my fears,
Are that those drops will change to bloody teares.
This woman, and this Serpent.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Drag him hence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Who dares lay hands upon me, Lords of Spain
Let your swords bail me, this false Queen did lye.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I'le fight with thee, damn'd hell-hound for my life.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I'le prove upon thy head.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Lords stop this villains throat.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Shal die, shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Words are ill spent,
Where wrong sits Judg, you'r arm'd if innocent.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Well, then I must to prison: Moor, no more:
Heavens thou art just, Prince Philip I betraid,
And now my self fall: Guile with guile is paid.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Philip being prov'd a bastard; who shall sit
Upon this empty throne?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Strumpet, not you.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Strumpet! and I not sit there! who then?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Down;
Back, if she touch it shee'l bewitch the chair;
This throne belongs to Isabel the fair,
Bring forth the Princes drest in royal robes,
The true affecter of Alvero's son,
Virtuous Hortenzo. Lords, behold your Queen.

div.head: Scena. II.
div.stage: Enter Isabella led in, in royal robes. Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: THou villain! what intendst thou, savage slave?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: To advance virtue thus, and thus to tread
On lust, on murther, on adulteries head.
Look Lords upon your Sovereign Isabel,
Though all may doubt the fruits of such a Womb,
Is she not like King Philip? let her rule.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: She rule?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: She rule? I shee.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: A child to sway an empire? I am her Protectress;
I'le pour black curses on thy damned head,
If thou wrongst me. Lords, Lords!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain,
Be deaf, be blind, hear not, behold her not,
She kill'd my virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: He kill'd your King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: 'Twas in my just wrath.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: 'Twas to get his Crown.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: His Crown! why here 'tis: thou slewst my Maria,
To have accesse to my unstained bed.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: 'Tis true, how often have I stopt
Thy unchast songs from passing through mine ears?
How oft, when thy luxurious arms have twin'd
About my jetty neck, have I cry'd out
Away, those scalding veins burn me 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Divel, 'tis a lie.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thou slewst my sweet Maria;
Alvero 'twas thy daughter, 'twas: Hortenzo,
She was thy sister; Justice Isabella!
This Serpent poison'd thy dear fathers bed,
Setting large horns on his Imperial head.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hah! why?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam you shall be heard,
Before the Courts, before the Courts of Spain

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A guard, a guard.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: A guard; for what? for whom?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: To wait on you,
So many great sins must not wait with few.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Keep me in prison! dare you Lords?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Oh no!
Were your cause strong, we would not arm you so;
But honor fainting needeth many hands,
Kingdoms stand safe, when mischief lies in bands:
You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Must I? must I, slave!
I'le dam thee, ere thou triumph'st o're my grave.

div.head: Scena. III.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: DO, do! my jocund spleen;
It does, it will, it shall, I have at one throw,
Rifled away the Diademe of Spain;
'Tis gone, and there's no more to set but this
At all, then at this last cast I'le sweep up
My former petty losses, or lose all.
Like to a desperate Gamester; hah! how? fast?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Except their bodies turn to airy spirits,
And fly through windows, they are fast my Lord:
If they can eat through locks and barrs of Iron,
They may escape, if not? then not.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ho! Zarack!
Wit is a thief, there's pick-lock policie,
To whom all doors flye open: therefore go,
In our name charge the Keeper to resign
His office; and if he have tricks of cruelty,
Let him bequeath'em at his death, for kill him;
Turn all thy body into eyes,
And watch them, let those eyes like fiery comets
Sparkle out nothing but the death of Kings.
And. ah! now thus thou know'st I did invent,
A torturing Iron chain.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Oh! for necks my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I that, that, that, away and yoak them, stay
Here's Balt. go both, teach them to preach,
Through an Iron Pillory: I'le spread a net,
To catch Alvero, oh! he's is old and wise,
They are unfit to live, that have sharp eyes, Hortenzo, Roderigo, to't, to't all:
They have supple knees sleack'd brows, but hearts of gall:
The bitterness shallbe wash'd off with blood,
Tyrants swim safest in a crimson flood.

sp.speaker: Balt
sp.l: I com to tel your grace that Isabella,
Is with Hortenzo arm in arm at hand,
Zarack and I may kill them, now with ease,
Is't done. and then 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Murther thou the man,
And I'le stab her.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: No, I'le speed her my selfe,
Arm in arm, so, so, look upon this Ring,
Who ever brings this token to your hands
Regard not for what purpose, seiz on them,
And chain them to the rest, they com, away,
Murder be proud, and Tragedy laugh on,
I'le seek a stage for thee to jett upon.

div.stage: Enter Isabella, Hortenzo, seeing the Moor turn back.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Lord! my Lord Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: Hah! is't you,
Trust me I saw you not.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What makes your grace so sad?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She grievs for the imprisoned Queen her Mother,
And for Philip, in the sandy heap,
That wait upon an hour, there are not found
So many little bodies as those sighs
And tears, which she hath every Minute spent,
Since her lov'd Brother felt Imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Pity, great pity, would it lay in mee,
To give him liberty.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: It does.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: In me?
Free him, your Mother Queen, and Cardinall too.
In me? alas! not me, no, no, in you;
Yet for I'le have my conscience, white and pure,
Here Madam take this Ring, and if my name
Can break down Castle walls, and open Gates,
Take it, and do't, fetch them all forth: and yet,
'Tis unfit you should go.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That happy office I'le execute
My selfe.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Will you? would I,
Stood gracious in their sight: well, go,
Do what you will Hortenzo, if this charm
Unbinds them, here 'tis; Lady, you and I
Aloof will follow him, and when we meet,
Speak for me, for I'le kisse Philippo's feet.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I shall be proud to see all reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Alas! my Lord, why true, go, go.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Make hast dear love.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hortenzo is a man
Compos'd of sweet proportion, ha's a foot,
A leg, a hand, a face, an eye, a wit,
The best Hortenzo in the Spanish Court.
Oh! he's the Nonpareil.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Your tongue had wont,
To be more sparing in Hortenzo's praise.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I, I may curse his praises, rather ban
Mine own nativity, why did this colour,
Dart in my flesh so far? oh! would my face
Were of Hortenzo's fashion, else would your
Were as black as mine is.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Mine like yours, why?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hark!
I love you, yes faith, I said this, I love you
I do, leave him.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Damnation vanish from me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Coy? were you as hard as flint Oh! you shou'd yield
Like softned wax, were you as pure as fire,
I'le touch you, yes, I'le taint you, see you this,
I'le bring you to this lure.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: If I want hands
To kill my self, before thou do'st it; do.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I'le cut away your hands: wel my desire
Is raging as the Sea, and mad as fire,
Will you?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Torment me not good Devill.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Will you?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: I'le tear mine eyes out if they tempt thy lust;

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Touch me not, these knives.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I, I, kill your selfe,
Because I jest with you: I wrong Hortenzo?
Settle your thoughts, 'twas but a trick to try,
That which few women have, true constancy.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: If then my speeches tast of gall.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nay faith,
You are not bitter, no, you should have rail'd,
Have spit upon me, spurn'd me, you are not bitter;
Why do you think that I'de nurse a though,
To hurt your honour? If that thought had brains,
I'de beat them out, but come, by this, Hortenzo
Is fast.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Hah! fast?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I fast in Philip's arms.
Wrestling together for the price of love;
By this, they're on the way, I'le be your guard,
Come follow me, I'le lead you in the van,
Where thou shalt see four chins upon one chain.

div.head: Scena IV.
div.stage: Enter Hortenzo, Queen Mother, Cardinall, and Philip chaind 'by the necks, Zarack, and Baltazar busie about fastning Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: YOu damned Ministers of villany,
Sworn to damnation by the book of hell;
You maps of night, you element of Devills,
Why do you yoak my neck with Iron chains?

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Many do borrow chains, but you have this
Gratis, for nothing.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Slaves unbind us.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: No—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am impatient, veins why crack you not?
And tilt your blood into the face of heaven
To make red clouds like Ensignes in the sky,
Displaying a damn'd tyrants cruelty;
Yet can I laugh in my extreamest pangs,
Of blood, and spirit, to see the Cardinall,
Keep ranck with me, and my vile Mother Queen,
To see her self, where she would have mee seen.
Good fellowship I'faith.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: And I can tell,
True misery, loves a companion wel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou left'st me to the mercy of a Moor,
That hath damnation dy'd upon his flesh;
'Twas well, thou Mother did'st unmotherly
Betray thy true son to false bastardy:
Thou left'st me then, now thou art found; and staid,
And thou who did'st betray me, art betraid.
A plague upon you all.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thou cursest them,
Whom I may curse; first may I curse my self,
Too credulous of Loyalty and love;
Next may I curse the Moor, more then a Devill.
And last thy Mother, mother of all evill.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: All curses, and all crosses light on thee,
What need I curse my selfe, when all curse mee.
I have been deadly impious I confesse,
Forgive mee, and my sin will seem the less:
This heavie chain which now my neck assault,
Weighs ten times lighter then my heavie faults.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hortenzo, I commend my self to thee,
Thou that art near'st, stand'st furthest off from mee.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: That mold of Hell, that Moor has chain'd me here,
'Tis not my self, but Isabel I fear.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: IT's strange! will not Prince Philip come with Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: He swears he'l live and die there.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Marry, and shall;
I pray perswade him you, to leave the place,
A prison? why its hell; Alas here they be,
Hah! they are they i'faith, see, see, see, see.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Moor, Devill, toad, serpent.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Oh sweet airs, sweet voices.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Oh my Hortenzo!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do not these birds sing sweetly Isabella?
Oh! how their spirits would leap aloft and spring,
Had they their throats at liberty to sing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Damnation dog thee.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Furies follow thee.

sp.speaker: Qu Mo.
sp.l: Cometts confound thee.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: And hell swallow thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Sweeter and sweeter still, Oh! harmony,
Why there's no musick like to miserie.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Hast thou betrai'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Not I, not I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirrah, hedge-hog.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hah! I'le hear thee presently.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Hear me then, Hell-hound; slaves, Unchain my love,
Or by—

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By what? is't not rare walking here.
Me thinks this stage shews like a Tennis Court;
Do's it not Isabell? I'le shew thee how:
Suppose that Iron chain to be the line,
The prison doors the hazard, and their heads
Scarce peeping ore the line suppose the bals;
Had I a racket now of burnish'd steel,
How smoothly could I bandy every ball,
Over this Globe of earth, win sett and all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How brisk the villain jetts in villany?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Prating? he's proud because he wears a chain:
Take it off Baltazar, and take him hence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And whither then you dog?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Pity my brother.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Pity him, no; away I come, do, come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I pray thee kill me: come.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I hope to see
Thy own hands do that office, down with him.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Is there another hell?

sp.speaker: 2 Moors.
sp.l: Try, try, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: So him next, he next, and next him; and then?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Worse then damnation, feind, monster of men.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why, when? down, down.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Slave, as thou thrusts me down,
Into this dungeon, so sink thou to hell.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Together so, and you.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: O pity my Hortenzo!

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Farewel sweet Isabel, my life adieu.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Mischief and horror let the Moor pursue.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A consort, that amain, play that amain.
Amain, Amain. No; so soon fallen asleep,
Nay I'le not loose this musick, sirrah! sirrah!
Take thou a drum, a Trumpet thou, and Hark;
Mad them with villanous sounds.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Rare sport, let's go.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: About it. Musick will doe well, in woe;
How like you this?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: set my Hortenzo free,
And I'le like any thing.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A fool, a fool?
Hortenzo free; why look you, hee free? no;
Then must he marry you, you must be Queen,
Hee in a manner King, these dignities
Like poyson make men swell, this Ratsbane honour
O 'tis so sweet, they'le lick it till all burst.
Hee will be proud, and pride you know must fall.
Come, come, he shall not; no, no; 'tis more meet,
To keep him down, safe standing on his feet.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Eleazar?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Mark: the imperial chair of Spain,
Is now as empty as a Misers Alms;
Be wise, I yet dare fit in't, it's for you,
If you will be for me, there's room for two.
Do meditate, muse on't: it's best for thee
To love me, live with me, and lye with me.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Thou knowst I'le first lye in the arms of death,
My meditations are how to revenge,
Thy bloody tyrannies; I fear thee not
Inhumane slave, but to thy face defie
Thy lust, thy love, thy barbarours villany.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Zarack.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Where's Baltazar?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: A drumming.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: I have made them rave, and curse, and
So; guard her:
Your Court shall be this prison, guard her slaves,
With open eyes; defie me? see my veins,
Struck't out, being over heated with my blood,
Boyling in wrath: I'le tame you.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hah!
I wil, and once more fil a kingdoms Throne
Spain I'le new-mould thee, I will have a chair
Made all of dead mens bones, and the ascents
Shall be the heads of Spaniards set in ranks;
I will have Philip's head, Hortenzo's head,
Mendoza's head, thy Mothers head, and this,
This head that is so crosse, I'le have't:
The Scene wants Actors, I'le fetch more, and cloth it
In rich Cothurnall pompe. A Tragedy
Ought to be grave, graves this shall beautifie.
Moor execute to'th life my dread commands,
Vengeance awake, thou hast much work in hand.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I'm weary of this office, and this life,
It is too thirsty, and I would your blood,
Might scape the filling out: By heaven I swear,
I scorn these blows, and his rebukes to bear.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Oh! Zarack pity me, I Iove thee well,
Love deserves pity, pity Isabel.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: To kill this Moor.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I'le cast an eye of death upon my, face.
I'le be no more his slave, swear to advance me;
And by yo'n setting sun, this hand, and this
Shall rid you of a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: By my birth;
No Spaniards honour'd place shall equall thine.

sp.speaker: Zarack
sp.l: I'le kill him then.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: And Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: And hee,

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: I pray thee first, fetch Philippo & Hortenzo
Out of that Hell; they two will be most glad
To ayd thee; in this Execution;

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My Lord Philippo; and Hortenzo; rise;
Your hands; so, talk to her; at my return
This sword shall reek with blood of Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Three curses (like three comendations
To their three soules) I send; thy tortur'd brother
Does curse the Cardinall, the Moor, thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Curse not at all dear soules; revenge is hot,
And boyles in Zaracks brains; the plot is cast,
Into the mold of Hell: You freemen are;
Zarack will kill the Moor; and Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: How can that relish?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Why? I'le tell you how?
I did profess; I, and protested too:
I lov'd him well, what will not sorrow do?
Then he profest; I, and protested too
To kill them both, what will not devils do?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then I profess; I, and protest it too,
That here's for him, what will not Philip do?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: See where hee coms.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Zarack, what do I see?
Hortenzo and Philip, who did this?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Thou art halfe damn'd for it, I'le to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.p: I'le stop you on your way, lie there; thy tongue shal tel no tales to day Stabs him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor thine to morrow, his revenge was well.
By this time both the slaves shake hands in hel.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Philippo and Hortenzo stand you still, what; doat you both? cannot you see your play? well fare a woman then, to lead the way. Once rob the dead, put the Moors habits on, and paint your faces with the oil of hell, so waiting on the Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: Come no more, 'tis here, and here; room there below, stand wide, bury them well since they so godly di'd.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Away then, fate now let revenge be plac'd.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And here, a tyrants blood doth sweetly tast.

div.head: Act V.
Scena VI.
div.stage: Enter Eleazar, Alvero, Roderigo, Christofero, and other Lords.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: WHat, I imprison, who?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Philip and Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Philip and Hortenzo, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roder
sp.l: Why laughs the Moor?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.p: I laugh because you jest; laugh at a jest, who I imprison them? I prize their lives with weights, their necks with chains, their hands with Manacles? do I all this, because my face is in nights colour dy'd.
Think you my conscience and my soul is so,
Black faces may have hearts as white as snow
And 'tis a generall rule in morall rowls,
The whitest faces have the blackest souls.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: But touching my Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: Good old man, I never touch'd him, do not touch me then with thy Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Christofero.
sp.l: Where's Philip too?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And where's Philippo too? I pray I pray, is Philip a tame Spaniard, what can I philip him hither, hither make him flye. First where's Hortenzo, where's Philippo too?

sp.speaker: Roderigo.
sp.l: And where is Isabel, she was with you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And where is Isabel, she was with me, and so are you, yet are you well you see but in good time, see where their keepers come. Come hither Zarack, Baltazar, come hither; Zarack, old Lord Alvero asks of thee, where young Hortenzo is.

div.stage: Enter Philip and Hortenzo like Moors.

sp.speaker: Horten
sp.l: My Lord! set free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.p:
Oh is he so; come hither Baltazar,
Lord Christofero here would ask of thee where Prince Philippo is.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Lord set free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Oh is he so! Roderigo asketh mee for Isabel,

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.l: I say my Lord shee's free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Oh! is she so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Believe me Lords.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: And mee.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: I set Philippo.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: I Hortenzo free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Lords because you shal believe me too,
Go to the Castle, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Thanks to the mighty Moor, and for his fame,
Be more in honour, then thou art in name;
But let me wish the other prisoners well,
The Queen and Cardinall, let all have right,
Let law absolve them or disolve them quite.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Grave man, thy gray hairs paint our gravity,
Thy counsells wisedom, thy wit pollicie.
There let us meet, and with a general brain,
Erect the peace of spirit and of Spain.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Then will Spain flourish.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I, when it is mine.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: O heavenly meeting!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: we must part in hell.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: True peace of joy.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.p: 'Tis a dissembling knel. Farewell my Lords, meet there so ha, ha, ha.

Now Tragedy thou Minion of the night, Rhamnusias pew-fellow; to thee I'le sing Upon an harp made of dead Spanish bones, The proudest instrument the world affords; When thou in Crimson jollitie shalt Bath, Thy limbs as black as mine, in springs of blood; still gushing from the Conduit-head of Spain: To thee that never blushest, though thy cheeks are full of blood. O! Saint revenge to thee: I consecrate my Murders, all my stabs, my bloody labours, tortures, stratagems: The volume of all wounds, that wound from me; mine is the stage, thine is the Tragedy. Where am I now? oh at the prison? true, Zarack and Baltazar come hither see, survey my Library. I study, I, whil'st you two sleep, marry 'tis villany. Here's a good book, Zarack behold it well, it's deeply written for 'twas made in hell. Now Baltazar, a better book for thee, but for my selfe, this, this, the best of all; and therefore do I chain it every day, for fear the Readers steal the art away. Where thou stand'st now, there must Hortenzo hang, Like Tantalus in a maw-eating pang: there
Baltazar must Prince Philip stand, like damn'd Prometheus, and to act his part; shal have a dagger sticking at his heart. But in my room I'le set the Cardinall, and he shal preach Repentance to them all. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Damnation tickles him, he laughs again, Philip must stand there and bleed to death: Well villain I onely laugh to see, that we shal live to out-laugh him and thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: Oh! fit, fit, fit, stay a rare jest, rare jest. Zarack, suppose thou art Hortenzo now? I pray thee stand in passion of a pang, to see by thee how quaintly he would hang.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I am Hortenzo, tut, tut, fear not man, thou lookest like Zarack.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: I Hortenzo, here hee shall hang here, I'faith, come Zarack come, and Baltazar take thou 〈◊〉 room. First let me see you plac'd

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We're plac'd.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p:
Slaves, ha, ha, ha, you are but players, they must end the play: how like Hortenzo and Philippo ha, stand my two slaves, were they as black as you. Well Zarack I'le unfix thee first of all, thou shalt help me to play the Cardinall; This Iron engine on his head I'le clap, like a Popes Miter, or a Cardinalls Cap. Then Manacle his hands as thou dost mine: so, so, I pray
thee Zarack set him free, that both of you may stand and laugh at mee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis fine I'faith, cal in more company,
Alvero, Roderigo, and the rest,
Who will not laugh at Eleazars jest.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What? Zarack, Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I, anon, anon, we have not laught enough, it's but begun.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Unmanacle my hands I say.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then shall we mar our mirth and spoil the play.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Alvero.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let Alvero in.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And let me out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I thank you for that flout,
To let Alvero in, and let you out.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Villains, slaves, am I not your
Lord the Moor, and Eleazar.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: And the Devil of hell,
And more then that, and Eleazar too.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And Devills dam, what do I here with you.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: My tongue shall torture thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: I know thee then, all womens tongues are tortures unto men.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.p:
Spaniards this was the villain, this is he who through enticements of alluring lust, and glory which makes silly women proud, and men malicious, did incense
my spirit beyond the limits of a womans mind, to wrong my self and that Lord Cardinall; And that which sticks more near unto my blood, he that was nearest to my blood; my son to dispossesse him of his right by wrong. Oh! that I might embrace him on this brest, which did enclose him when he first was born. No greater happinesse can heaven showre upon me; then to circle in these arms of mine, that son whose Royall blood I did defame, to Crown with honour an ambitious Moor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thus then thy happinesse is compleat:
Behold thy Philip ransom'd from that prison
In which the Moor had cloistered him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And here's Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: Then am I betray'd and cozen'd in my own designs: I did contrive their ruine, but their subtil policie hath blasted my ambitious thoughts: Villains! where's Zarack? where's Baltazar? what have you done with them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
They're gon to Pluto's kingdom to provide a place for thee, and to attend thee there; but least they should be tyr'd with too long expecting hopes. Come brave spirits of Spain, this is the Moor the actor of these
evils: Thus thrust him down to act amongst the devills.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And am I thus dispatch'd; had I but breath'd the space of one hour longer, I would have fully acted my revenge. But oh! now pallid death bids me prepare, and hast to Charon for to be his fare.

I com, I com, but ere my glasse is run, I'le curse you all, and cursing end my life Maist thou Lascivious Queen whose damned charms, bewitch'd me to the circle of thy arms, unpitied dye, consumed with loathed lust, which thy venereous mind hath basely nurst. And for you Philip, may your days be long, but clouded with perpetuall misery. May thou Hortenzo, and thy Isabell, be fetch'd alive by Furies into hell, there to be damn'd for ever, oh! I faint; Devills com claim your right, and when I am, confin'd within your kingdom then shall I, out-act you all in perfect villany.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Take down his body while his blood streams forth, his acts are past, and our last act is done. Now do I challenge my Hereditary right, to th' Royall Spanish throne usurp'd by him. In which, in all your sights I thus do plant my self. Lord Cardinall, and you the Queen my mother, I pardon all those crimes you have committed.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I'le now repose my self in peacefull rest,
And flye unto some solitary residence;
Where I'le spin out the remnant of my life,
In true contrition for my past offences.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And now Hortenzo to close up your wound,
I here contract my sister unto thee,
With Comick joy to end a Tragedie.
And for this Barbarous Moor, and his black train,
Let all the Moors be banished from Spain.

div.trailer: The end of the fifth Act.
